title: Spectacular but awkward!
review: Let's just say no wonder why Leonardo DiCaprio hardly received any nomination for this role. The movie itself is way longer than it should be. They could tell this story in a shorter time. Although there were really spectacular scenes (btw the scene in the red room was really awkward) and the ending was intenese those weren't able to save this from being a film you wouldn't watch again.

title: LANA DEL RAY WILL YOU STILL LOVE ME!!
review: That song plays 38 different ways, 87 different times during the course of this whole movie. Besides that, love Leonardo. It was okay 6/10

title: tired of comparisons between this movie and the book!!!
review:
Before watching The Great Gatsby, I was wondering to postpone watching it. once the film started, for the next 143 minutes I didn't understand the passage of time.
It is a 2013 American romantic drama film based on F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1925 novel of the same name, directed by Baz Luhrmann. It is the story of a mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby (by Leonardo DiCaprio) and His only Love of Life. the cast were perfect, Leonardo DiCaprio had an awesome performance, and he was completely successful in showing the complexity of his character. The visual effects of the movie were also excellent, colors, designs and costumes were wonderful.
Mixing modern music with 1920 music was maybe one of the weaknesses of Baz Luhrman great Gatsby. (really disappointing)
After all, if you're going to watch the movie with the idea of comparing it with the book you will spend an awful 2 hours and half, but if you watch it like every other film which are telling a story it is definitely worth seeing.

title: Better but with poor ending.
review: Movie was quiet better.but the end of this movie,killed the beauty of it.though i was a great story.and combination of leonardo's and tobey was so Awesome.

title: Nothing special
review: Top actor in the lead. However, only in his name and acting, this film is not average, although the other parameters belong to that level. A lot of kitsch, trash, madness in the foreground. I expected more from this movie, but sometimes you get, you'll lose sometime! I wish the shop was more sensible, and not somehow unconnected and scattered. Maybe I'm wrong about the action, but so fast everything happens in the movie so I can not get half the stuff. The film is dying!

title: Not my cup of tea
review: I think this movie will suit anyone who loved Moulin Rouge. Unfortunately I didn't and this movie suffered from the same drawbacks for me. It was too garish, loud and modern in it's soundtrack. I love the era of the 1920s and love the music as well, so I would have preferred some suitable music. Baz Luhrmann's flair is well known and he is very talented. The cast are very good and the story (as far as I know) was shown well. But it didn't suit me and so I can't rate it highly. I love Carey Mulligan and Tobey Maguire, and I liked most of the other cast members. Leonardo DiCaprio is now an established mature actor and having recently seen The Aviator, his Gatsby reminded me of Howard Hughes in terms of his excesses (although not in his paranoia). Just a cautionary note that the visuals are very hectic and this is not your typical costume drama, but the anyone who know Luhrmann's style should know that.

title: Gatsby really Great?
review:
I never had read the book but because of Dicaprio and Decki's birthday, I thought of giving this movie a try. But to my dismay, there was no character development at all. I mean no matter how hard did Maguire tried to elevate Dicaprio's status, it all remained flat and served no purpose. Even the writers didn't cared for showing Mulligan displaying any regret after DiCaprio's death.

Where was the greatness in Gatsby? He could have run an orphanage in the later half of the movie to show that: a) the movie and the book differ in each other. b) how really the movie ends in a satisfying note and surprise the audience that Gatsby was not materialistic after all.

The only positive part was the soundtrack and DiCaprio's romance in the cruise boat with Mulligan.

title: Good but could have been great
review: I quite enjoyed the Great Gatsby but felt it had all the ingredients to be a classic and these ingredients were not all used. Leonardo gives a great performance as Gatsby and so does the rest of the cast. The cinematography was outstanding and made the film alluring and graceful. However better direction could have made the film more dramatic. Perhaps the film could have been arranged differently with the use of voice overs or other techniques to heighten some parts and not others. The Great Gatsby is a classic novel but bringing it to life in a different medium is a different story altogether. Still a great watch and entertaining.

title: Disappointing and far too 'Gothic' not much of Fitzgerald there.
review: I have tried to see merit in this interpretation, but I cannot see much to applaud. There is no softness, everything,especially the houses and apartments are dripping with sexual references which to an oldie like me are very boring. The characters are not sympathetic or interesting - more like caricatures. The depiction of Wolfshein is bordering on anti- Semitic and the Wilsons are without any depth at all. Sorry, director but Fitzgerald is simply not your forte, I will not be watching this again unlike some of the earlier film versions which I have watched over and over and still get something different each time.

title: Decent, but not good or great
review:
The reason why I say that Baz Luhrmann's adaptation is terribly overrated is because this movie is supposed to be based on the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel but the movie doesn't stay true to the book more than book to film adaptations normally do even though I am not normally a person to criticize a movie because of those factors, though I won't give anything major to this film away in this review. This time around the movie stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby who is a well known businessman and is one of the richest if not the richest person where he lives. There are a lot of key major differences between this movie and the Robert Redford version that was made 39 years earlier. This movie also depicts Gatsby as a man who has parties in a modern fashion but another key problem I had with this movie is also that it didn't completely stay true to the period in which the story was supposed to be set in.

Also this movie despite having such a good cast the movie is horribly over-acted, and the only thing I liked about the film was the production design and the costumes.

Also in this movie are the accurate characters such as Daisy (Carey Mulligan),Tom Buchanan (Joel Edgerton),George Wilson (Jason Clarke) and his wife Myrtle (Isla Fisher), as well as Gatsby's good friend that he met in the beginning of the movie Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire).

However there are some things that director Baz Luhrmann actually got right, such as the love affair between Gatsby and Daisy, the "old sport" exchange between Gatsby and Tom, and many other scenes.

In the end I didn't like or dislike this movie but even though the movie deserved the two Oscars that it won three years ago. I happen to think that if it stayed true to the period, and wasn't over-acted, that it could have been a better movie (even though it was good) with a hell of a lot better storytelling it was an OK movie even though I do agree with what Roger Ebert once said about accuracy in movies to Gene Siskel in which he said that "A movie doesn't have to be accurate in order to be good."

title: Razzle-Dazzle Gatsby
review:
Luhrmann is an exceptional director. Not in the sense that he is extraordinarily competent, consistent and deep, but rather he is a one of a kind visual pioneer. His fast paced, unusual, anachronic dazzling and lush visual signature though are not suitable for every material.

With Moulin Rouge! he gave us an extraordinarily unusual film where his ecstatic style could exist and had more than enough room to grow. While The Great Gatsby material allows for some of such liberties to exist, Luhrmann lacks editorial notion: while the partying flair is on point, all the rest is taken either too far or too short at times. The characters motivations and inner struggles are completely overwhelmed by the overbearing sets, cinematography and score (all of them amazing truth be told) and music video-like editing that never allows us to delve or empathize with them. Luhrmann even manages to make DiCaprio feel flat and out of place and Mulligan miscast. What we are left with is a 2-hour-plus long music video with talking passages, that while visually stunning and musically memorable, feels frustrating considering the source material's potentials and the talent involved.

title: A story of love nobody truly cares for
review:
Baz Luhrmann's "The Great Gatsby" was an interesting mix of a bunch of parties, CGI, and a love story. Gatsby's longing for his lover, Daisy, seemed too forced and shallow for one to care for. The film seemed too over saturated with the CGI and fast cuts. Too much relocation of the eyes were required to figure out what was going on in a particular shot. It's as if I was watching the new Jason Bourne action flick with every shot being less than 2 seconds, which really hinders the film's feeling of a grand spectacle. The sound was off as well. There was too much unnecessary sound effects, especially with the ringing hymn of the green light/ring every 5 minutes. I went into this movie expecting a traditional story and feeling of the roaring 20s, not an old story adapted with an overly modern score to replace the amazing jazz music of that era.

Eyes play an important role in the Great Gatsby. Eyes are a symbol of the rich overlooking the poor, almost as if they own the large working class. The haunting feeling of one person sitting at home enjoying life with all of their money bossing around the other 95% of the people which makes up the working class. The billboard was situated to be erected right in the middle of the bad industrial part of the town (The Valley of Ashes). It can also be interpreted as a higher being looking down onto American society as a whole, and it being disappointed of how shallow people are in the context of the rich people covering up their act with all of their glamorous items of pleasure, and in return, they demoralize the common person. People lost their true moral values to get external pleasures, and the eyes can see through this fatal flaw of mankind.

The opening lines of the film relate to these eyes because Nick's father gave him the advice of always trying to see the best in people. This reflects how the eyes see through the people, but the difference is is that at that time (20s) there was no best in most people. It mostly just consisted of humans partying and not contributing anything important or worthwhile. This opening line says it all "And none of us contributed anything new. When I came back from New York, I was disgusted....Disgusted with everyone and everything." Another symbol is the green light. It's as if Gatsby was always looking at it because he wanted to reach further, and advance his life even more even though he should just look back onto his life and notice that he has it pretty good already. The green light is situated away from his house across the water, while all of his life and his big house is situated behind him towards his back.

Daisy and Tom represent the old rich. They have their status and their wealth through family history. They are the stereotypical rich, high class people. On the other hand, Mr. Gatsby is the new rich. Although he seems at first to be just another rich person, underneath he stands out from the rest of the population in that he comes from humble beginnings and he is a truly caring person. Daisy goes with Tom instead of Gatsby because he has status. If Daisy leaves him, she loses that status and all of the wealth that goes with it. This is why she went with him in the first place. When Gatsby was in the war, Daisy wrote Gatsby a letter saying she has no money. Therefore, she married Buchanan, following a shot of him wrapping a plentiful amount of pearls around her neck.

There are four main locations in the film. The first being West egg, then East Egg, then New York, and The Valley of Ashes. West egg represents the new rich, which encompasses people such as Mr. Gatsby. East Egg represents the old rich, which includes Tom Buchanan. New York represents the action and the central location where most the fun happens. And The Valley of Ashes represents the poor working class of the population, where people like George Wilson reside.

title: The 1974 film disguised as a 2013 film
review: Baz Luhrmann is an accomplished Hollywood director, no doubt about it. However, when he created this movie he really must have had his fingers crossed that no one out there actually watched Jack Clayton's 1974 adaptation of The Great Gatsby because it is 92% a scene for scene rehash of the same exact movie(which btw wasn't well received which makes me wonder why originality was not discussed in the boardroom meetings). Quick copy checklist between the 1974 and 2013 films..Opening filming sequence introducing Tom and Daisy Buchanan along with Jordan Baker to Nick Carraway in the living room at the Buchanan household, COPY CHECK√ ..The Jay Gatsby logo JG, COPY CHECK√ The first meeting between Daisy Buchanan and Jay Gatsby at the Carraway house, COPY CHECK√ even the dirt road with the forks outside Tom and Myrtle Wilson's gas station where the billboard of the ever-watchful eyes of Dr. T.J. Eckleburg lay, COPY CHECK√. Lots more, but I like to keep it short+sweet. Call it an unfair review but when you translate book to film you create magic the first time, and the only way to duplicate that magic a second time and so on is by being bold, daring and fresh. In an era of crowd pleasing movies where the audience begs and cries for originality (Inception, TY Mr. Christopher Nolan) I am not sure how this movie made it past the green light phase. Leonardo Dicaprio's name and presence alone probably is the only reason why you or anyone else in 2013 who watched it, watched it. Thank goodness he is an intellectual actor and went on to star in better and greater films and Oscar glory (Wolf of Wall Street and The Revenant). Sorry Mr. Luhrmann, I'm sure it's not your fault this movie came out, bad pieces of celluloid are usually the brainchild of many. Please continue to make wonderful musicals and adaptations and hopefully your next movie is a success and you can put this one behind you, wayyyy wayyyyy behind you.

title: visually outstanding, besides being fun, more problematic with a rhythm
review: The Great Gatsby is a cool film, has good dialogue , the characters of DiCaprio and Tobey are very charismatic , both actors are good, Carey Mulligan is a good performance , the more your character is not so good , the direction is good at the beginning more is lost in the course of the film , now two very positive points in the film, the Photography and the Wardrobe , photography is excellent, the Visual is very beautiful, the moment of the party at Gatsby is too beautiful visually , the costume is impeccable , the characters dress perfectly for the time, the Great Gatsby is a cool movie , has a great shot , a good soundtrack and impeccable wardrobe , has problems in the script, a very slow pace , the film is a bit long , and the pace does not help , plus it worth watching , of to have a little fun . Note 6.6

title: Deciding how many stars to give
review:
I read the novel ages ago and agree it is a literary classic, though I also still believe it is *not* a "great American novel." Actually, it is F. Scott Fitzgerald who convinces me that there probably is no such thing. There are great works, great writing, great stories, &c., but no, no such thing as a great American novel. However, I *do* believe there is such a thing as a great (American optional) movie, er, film. Australians do qualify.

2 stars for production, set & scenery, costumes and makeup. Minus 1 star for CGI scenery & blue screen. Even in one scene when they are sitting indoors (I forgot which, maybe the waiting for 4 o'clock one) and there's a window in the back to the right showing the outdoors, I almost felt that what I was seeing out of the window was CGI. Even if I'm wrong, that's the impression I get, which is a bad impression to give to the viewer. The long lens overhead shots and so on of the city, Long Island,&c.--totally CGI and unnecessarily so polished that they actually look fake and ugly, ugly in a bad way not in an artsy fartsy way. Gatsby's palace belongs at Disney World. The smaller sets were better than the overall design. Nice pool.

1 star only for the screenplay. It lost a second star due to the awful dialogue and lack of narrative cohesiveness. The musical interludes, party, horn player on a balcony, &c., really interrupt the storytelling for flashy social commentary that don't really work for me. I think they were trying to make that part of the Fitzgerald story subtle but I think they failed. No, those elements did not entertain. The story flatlines for at least the first 30 minutes and doesn't get a heartbeat until we meet Leondardo Di'Gatsby.

1 star for music & sound. No second star due to the awful use of contemporary music. It's one thing to say that truly great music is timeless and one can almost lift this music here from this era and plop it into that spot there in that era. But to go backwards is not always a smart idea. Jazz can easily stand on its own TODAY, even in its early times like the Roarin' 20s, so why not just let the music of the era shine? Rapping on the soundtrack--sorry guys, the pieces selected are not going to stand the test of time, so I felt they were inappropriate. Dubstep: yeah, right. Have you seen them try to do the swing and Charleston to that stuff? Doesn't look as energetic or fitting as the original dance music, eh? no matter how hard they tried to get the music thumping. That type of dance is not about thumping, folks, it's about quick-stepping and swiveling on the balls of your feet, not a fist pumper.

Two stars for the acting, each owned by Tom (Joel Edgerton) and Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio). No more stars due to bland Tobey Maguire. No stars for the rest of the cast; they were merely adequate. Edgerton is deliciously unlikable yet sympathetic to us in the portrayal, not over the top but shows why the story must end miserably due to the privilege (but not prestige) of the haves against the have-nots that inevitably ends in carelessness taken to its logical conclusion. The mustache does most of the acting for him. DiCaprio is brilliant. It's not his fault the awful dialogue has him saying "Old Spor'" every other line--ugh! His body posture is nearly perfect, body language in motion is nice. Look at that seething face and the deep lean-in towards the end when they have that argument out in town and the place is sweltering hot. His seething, like a hot iron, is even hotter than a flame, not so much in terms of temperature but for what it does to the psyche. No additional stars for lack of romantic chemistry b/w Gatsby and Daisy. She actually has more on screen chemistry w/ her husband, against the story's wishes--can you believe that?

Editing: zero stars. I don't even want to say.

1 star only for the directing. I give up to 5 stars for the directing alone (Oscar quality, possibly an all-time classic). 4 stars: I highly recommend as a "should watch" for the year. But no, B.L. is so bad at helping out the cinematographer, especially in tight spaces like dinner/tea/lunch dialogues, his "vision"--blech--overshadows the fluidity of the scene. Can you say too many chandeliers getting in the way at the table? Is this supposed to be some subtle hint? supporting material of the physical world mimicking/supporting the emotional and psychological world? If so, it is too heavy-handed. If not, that's just an awful distraction of glitz and glam on the screen. It is everywhere sparkly and lush, even when dust is supposed to be settling on the furniture. But no, B.L. doesn't know how to shoot a scene straight. I am neutral on the over-the-top set pieces: grand party scenes, car accident scene w/ victim slo-mo hurling through the air, &c. &c. He is directing like he's ordering around all those folks in maid & butler costumes and calls it vision, like the psychological motivator of Gatsby. One sees what Fitzgerald thinks about all that... 'nough said.

Production, the rest of it: zero to one stars. I took one star away from the costume and set design, &c. above. Here, I'm talking mostly the post- production and overall feel of the picture (not its look). The jewelry and hat designs outshone the sweeping gray downtown New York landscape and cut-ins and overlays over the stars and clouds and the green light. Ugh. I could go on. Point is those types of production tricks take away from Fitzgerald's nearly lyrical prose. It felt "tricky" not artistic.

OK, total something like 6 stars, which feels right to me.

title: The original was better. 5/10
review:
Review: How can you make a movie about the 1920's with Hip Hop music? Anyway, I thought that the original was a much better movie. You can definitely tell that this film was made by the same people who made the Romeo & Juliet remake, which also started Leonardo DiCaprio, because the director really tries to make the all time classic, hip with the music and the CGI, but I didn't think that it suited this type of movie. The original storyline was great and it really didn't need any tricks or fancy shots, which was why I they should have just left this film alone. As for the actors, Leonardo DiCaprio done a great job playing Robert Redford's part as Gatsby but I'm not a big fan of Tobey Maguire's stiff way of acting. Anyway, the film is watchable, but they should have stuck which the original content.

Round-Up: I can't help thinking that the love of Leonardo DiCaprio's life throughout the movie was a bit of a bitch at the end because she didn't come clean about what really happened. She didn't even turn up to the funeral, knowing that the whole thing was a lie. Anyway, Leonardo is still making people rush to the cinema to watch his movie, judging by the money that it made, which just shows that it's all about the choice of movies. I don't find him the most versatile actor, but he has definitely has great screen charisma, which directors love working with. Carrey Mulligan has this innocent way of acting were she could be committing a murder but she still looks like she can't do any wrong. Throughout the movie she can't make up her mind if she is coming or going, which causes so many problems with all of the characters, but she still manages to look like she is the guilty party. Anyway, the party scenes looks amazing but the music was a bad choice by the director.

Budget: $105million Worldwide Gross: $349million

I recommend this movie to people who are into there who are fans of the original and who enjoyed the remake of Romeo & Juliet. 5/10

title: A bad adaptation
review: A shockingly bad adaptation. Given that I haven't read the book, but as is always the case with classics, 1 knows the story fairly well without ever having done that. The fault with the movie is mainly the direction, the book and the story has a certain vibe to it, a vibe that the movie tries to capture, but the tricky thing about vibes is that they are quite hard to create on screen, and even harder to maintain. 1 simply doesn't feel the flow of this movie, it tries, but scenes and the shots and the cutaways just don't line up as they should. Added to which the acting is very bad, yes it's true, despite the all star cast the acting is very bad. Everybody is bland and empty, it's like watching people recite lines, there are a few good scenes but most of it is dull. I'm keen to blame this on the director, clearly there was a sense of miscommunication somewhere. Or perhaps it was the sets that failed to pull them into character, they certainly failed to pull me into the movie.The whole thing looks like it was done in a sound stage with cheap CGI to fill in the cracks. In short, it's a bad adaptation of an interesting novel.

title: ★★★★★ The Great Gatsby
review:
@PiersFoleyPhoto: Gatsby shines through all the diamonds, extravagance and high class that is portrayed with a longing hope #PFPreview

I went into to this not really knowing what to expect, I'd read the book back in secondary school and have seen a few of Luhrmann's previous films. I was intrigued how they could work together. Knowing what he'd done with Romeo and Juliet it could safely assume that it would be modernised somewhat and would be a visual treat. Instantly you are greeted with an absolutely visually stunning film. Luhrmann's artistic direction, the stunning sets, costumes and cinematography and the seamless editing keep a high energy through the first twenty minutes or so. The modern soundtrack beautifully complements the visuals and fits strikingly seamlessly to the era. It's all a bit like a music video, and you really want to be a part of it all and you begin to feel like you are. On meeting Gatsby mid party Luhrmann slows the pace right down and you then float through like the drapes in the scene we first meet Daisy. Still with the fireworks in the background he zooms you in to the lives of the three leads and continues at the pace of Twenties slow, smooth jazz.

There are two occasions however when I felt thrown out of the escapist world I was immersed in on hearing reworkings of Beyoncé's Crazy in Love and Amy Winehouse's Back to Black seep in. It just inappropriately brought to mind Jay-Z (the otherwise enlightened choice of producing partner and songwriter of the film) and his wife. The two of them are hidden round the corner behind camera. Stood watching Gatsby and Carraway awaiting Daisy, Jay-Z pulls an early birthday present on Beyoncé, the promise of getting her in the movies again. And then Carey Mulligan pulls up in a car and Leo gets wet and we're back into the film. Back to Black (sung again by Beyoncé) has a somewhat more delicate working into the soundtrack but again it momentarily threw me out of the film.

The themes and morals of the original story could to some seem to get lost in the indulgent aesthetics but the outstanding supporting cast do play them throughout with such commanding subtlety. The tension of class and race divides, the criminal and social corruption of the prohibition era, the mania of First World War veterans drinking away their memories and 'shell-shock' is all there if you care to look for it. Luhrmann just chooses to concentrate more on the humanity of one man, and his love, and us as the audience perceiving it. This decision works and it's just as powerful as the social commentary of the era.

I wasn't too keen on the somewhat clichéd story telling device of Carraway writing for his therapist, not, to my memory, present in the novel. It does however serve its purpose and get the ball rolling. Tobey Maguire is fantastic as Carraway the narrator, he is the everyman, he is the audience. He like us witnesses everything that happens and similarly in powerless to change anything. What happens to Gatsby is ultimately inevitable, and he and we are the only ones left feeling the worse for it, and Maguire really does do the filmic Greek chorus justice. Carey Mulligan is mesmerisingly beautiful as Daisy; flirtatiously floating in and out of every shot. Her subtlety of emotion is extremely captivating. At times you can see her every thought process, of inner turmoil, on which path to take, all in a fleeting glance. The supporting cast are all unquestionably outstanding too but the two standouts really are Leonardo DiCaprio and Joel Edgerton. Edgerton does really well to show glimpses of sensitivity and vulnerability in Buchanan, the otherwise hard faced man of self believed righteousness. And then there's Leonardo DiCaprio.

DiCaprio, once again, does not fail to bring his incredible talent to this role. Perhaps not some people's obvious choice for Gatsby after the Redford film, but for me he is so much better. Leo takes this character to a whole new level of mystery, secret and ultimate humanity. The way we as an audience witness the plot and story of Gatsby's past unfold, we witness the mastery of DiCaprio unwind and reveal the character's emotions and desires. A strong symbol throughout is Gatsby staring out towards the green light across the water from his palace; a symbol of his longing hope to be with Daisy. The shot of DiCaprio's hand reaching for the light, for me, perfectly sums up his mastery of this character. You can see that it is a hand that has worked hard to get to where it is, to impress his one true love, yet it is well taken care of by the wealth it has acquired in the process. You can see the hand desires more than anything the touch of his love, yet it is evident that he is afraid of the rejection of that love and the difficulties of gaining it. It shows infinite hope of reaching that light. That's just his hand in one shot. The rest of his performance from the secretive swagger, to the welcoming grin he gives to Carraway, the way he plays with Edgerton and the last words he utters to his love are done with sheer mastery. Leonardo DiCaprio is without a doubt in the running for the Oscar and many more awards for this role. As indeed should be all involved in this production.

This is one of those rarer films that you walk out of the cinema and you feel you've had the full all round film experience. Visually stunning, immersive plot and soundtrack, perfect cast and above all affecting. My favourite film by far this year. Go and watch this film while it's still in the cinema! Go and see it in 3D!

title: The great boredom
review:
"The Great Gatsby" is a movie that convinces with well done visual effects even though they weren't worth a 3D adaption at all. The soundtrack of the movie was also decent as well as costumes, light work and locations. Leonardo DiCaprio did another convincing job but he has also done far better before as well.

These are the only positive things I could tell you about this boring movie based on a horribly overrated novel. There are so many bad points that I honestly don't really know where to start. The story is extremely lame and predictable. The main love story never managed to touch me even though I'm a rather emotional and romantic person. Even the disgusting and evil characters didn't evoke any kind of emotion in me. The only moments where something finally happens in the movie are maybe the last thirty minutes and it's not all too breathtaking neither. The first two hours are almost event-less and there isn't any character development neither. The acting is superficial and simply forgettable. It has been a while since I have seen a movie with such a bad and exchangeable acting. Especially the narrator and main character didn't give me anything at all and remained absolutely faceless. The movie tried to criticize the mindless life of the roaring twenties but its attempt remained dull and vague.

In the end, I was close to leave my local movie theatre several times and the film was really hard to sit through after all. This drama has a lot of lengths, includes mostly faceless actors and focuses on an ordinary story line that could be told in three lines and that doesn't carry a movie with an overrated length of two hours and a half. The costumes and effects are okay but not worth your money for an expensive 3D screening.

In the end, as a fan of many movies centred around the roaring twenties and the depressive thirties in the United States of America (from "The Godfather" over "Once Upon A Time In America" up to "Gangster Squad") and also as a fan of Leonardon DiCaprio in many of his movies ("Titanic", "Inception", "Shutter Island") I was really disappointed by this flick. I wouldn't watch it again and would recommend you to avoid this content-less piece of glam and glitter at all costs.

title: Dreadful visual experiencie
review: The worst movie I've seen in a long time.

title: 'The Great Gatsby' is worth seeing and might just be the best adaptation yet of the iconic novel.
review:
This is far from the first time someone has tried to adapt 'The Great Gatsby' to screen. Previous attempts include a 1926 silent film, a 1949 version directed by Elliot Nugent ('My Favorite Brunette'), the 1974 film with Robert Redford, and a 2000 television movie that starred Paul Rudd. I've seen the latter two, and while I enjoyed some of the performances, both came up weak in the end. Now we have Luhrmann, who seems to have blended Fitzgerald's novel with his own 'Moulin Rouge!' and given it a good wash. While its grand 3D visuals, techno-inspired epic parties, and a soundtrack by Jay-Z, Jack White and Beyoncé might strike a bitter chord with fans of the novel, rest assured that Luhrmann stays fairly faithful to the book.

'Gatsby' starts off in grainy black and white, as some dull music rolls out during the opening credits, which morph into highly colorful 3D as if the theatre curtains were drawn up to show us that green light from the end of Daisy's pier. We cut to Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire) in a therapist's office, trying to explain what went down in the summer of 1922 when he lived in West Egg, New York. As he begins, we get a montage of New York being built and the city's successes and declines. The archival footage mixed with the CG footage looks great with an impressive view of 1922 New York City. The only other film I've seen that has matched this detailed recreation of the old Big Apple was Peter Jackson's 'King Kong'.

We learn that Nick was a young graduate of Yale and wanted to try his hand on Wall Street. He moved into a small house smashed between two large riverfront mansions. Across the river are his old Yale buddy Tom Buchanan (Joel Edgerton) and his wife Daisy (Carey Mulligan). One of Nick's wealthy neighbors is the reclusive and impressive Jay Gatsby, who throws excessive and expensive parties almost every night, where politicians, gangsters, celebrities and socialites show up. However, none of them actually knows Gatsby or has even seen him before.

Not until 35 minutes into the film do we even get our first glimpse of Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio), with a brilliant entrance and introduction. He simply owns the world with his smile and confidence. On the other side of the lake, Daisy still longs for her long-lost love (Gatsby, of course), whom she had last seen five years earlier, before he left for the war. While he was away, she married Tom, who's a pompous bully, to put it lightly.

DiCaprio really puts his heart on his sleeve and bares his soul to be embraced or rejected by Daisy. DiCaprio's performance, as he awkwardly tries to talk with and move around the love he hasn't seen for many years, should win him an Oscar. It's endearing to watch this coming from a person like Gatsby.

Meanwhile, during the affair between Gatsby and Daisy, Tom has an affair of his own with Myrtle (Isla Fisher), the local wife of a man who runs a down-and-out garage on the outskirts of town. Their friend Jordan (Elizabeth Debiki), a golf pro and socialite, tries to keep Daisy happy and Tom unaware of what's transpiring until everyone ends up at the Plaza Hotel, spilling their guts about their feelings. This leads to car wreck, and then to Gatsby's pool, which might be the best shot scene in the movie.

Luhrmann really slows things down after an hour into the film so that we can see Gatsby's love for Daisy grow as he tries to recreate the passion from when they first met, even though Nick tells him that he can't repeat the past. It's here where we lose Nick in the story. He only serves to narrate from time to time and becomes a bit tedious as the other characters are far more interesting.

Maguire does a great job as Nick as far as that can go, being that he's more of a fly- on-the-wall and sides with Gatsby throughout, even though he might not have in the book. Edgerton plays a mean Tom to a tee. You hate the guy, but that's a good thing and he gives an amazing performance. Fisher and Debiki are solid as well whenever they're on-screen. Mulligan is charged with the difficult task of Daisy. Daisy is different for everyone. She is the American dream girl, which could be bad or good for some people. Mulligan does an okay job here, but I felt like I wanted more from her. She seems to tone down her role a bit, which leaves her relationship with Gatsby something less than desired. Truly shining above the rest is DiCaprio. He is Jay Gatsby. His persona, charm and character are flawless. He's truly larger than life here, and one of the best parts of the film. Every time he's off-screen, you want him back on-screen.

The picture itself is incredible with its detailed sets, lavish parties and amazing costumes. The film is also in 3D, which I found less than thrilling. Sure, it has some added depth, but it's mostly unnecessary and took me out of the story. I think the story could do just fine without the added effect.

With Luhrmann's beautiful direction and Jay-Z's music contribution (which is a breath of fresh air and I think coincides with Fitzgerald's love of modern music), 'The Great Gatsby' is worth seeing and might just be the best adaptation yet of the iconic novel. I can't wait to get my hands on this soundtrack and watch the movie on Blu- ray in glorious high definition.

title: Mesmerizing and captivating movie
review:
The simplicity behind the story is almost laughable, it's been done, and it's déjà-vu but The Great Gatsby plays its cards right. It's starts with the execution, the directing, the photography and the acting is impressive. You can see Baz Luhrmann's stamp throughout the film, it's colorful, loud, and a bit in your face but it works because it fits Nick (Tobey Maguire)'s point of view. Nick's the one telling the story, so the excess, the sensory overload, the overwhelming aspect of the fast life of the roaring 20s New York is exactly how a guy like Nick would experience it.

The director knows music and how to use it, and did an interesting job with it. The music of the past and the present are intertwined and it works. The familiarity of the present song are there but the 1920s beats takes you back and deeper into that lavish world.

The film is in its core a human story, with romance, drama, and a hint of mystery. The direction captures the themes and morals of the story really well but the actors' performances bring it home. Tobey Maguire's voice over and performance is nuanced, he's an observer and a participant at the same time in the film. Leonardo DiCaprio is at the peak of his powers, in full command of his acting abilities, he's brilliant in this film. Joel Edgerton, Elizabeth Debicki, and Isla Fisher should be mentioned because they were very good. Carey Mulligan is the one I wasn't completely sold on the first time around - she looked too young - but watching it again I get it and understand how she could have been cast in this film.

The Great Gatsby is entertaining and quite captivating, Baz Luhrmann knows how to shoot grand epic love stories.

Written by @wornoutspines

title: On balance...better than I'd expected
review: I was happy to consider this movie because of DiCaprio and the source material; but I had some nervousness too, because I'm not a great fan of Baz Luhrmann's previous fare. Indeed, there are times when the counter-contemporary music takes away from the experience, but it's not constant and didn't leave me with lasting disappointment. It is all a bit 'Busby Berkley' at times with some of the set pieces looking a little too staged and unbelievable for my liking. I get the creativity and splendour of what was in Luhrmann's vision, but with a period like the 20's - I don't think we need too much more glitter than was the case anyway. The positives outweigh these concerns though - DiCaprio is mysterious and enigmatic throughout and the supporting cast perform perfectly and compliment the visuals to create an eye-catching experience. Toby McGuire plays a cautious character, but grows in stature as the plot progresses - eventually standing as the only principled individual of the piece. So Baz - I'm not convinced that everything you do adds to the plot in a positive way, but on balance the experience of watching The Great Gatsby is one worth having.

title: I feel like I drank perfume with glitter in it for no reason
review:
Well, I've read a lot of Hemmingway and I would say that the original tale illustrates the futility of wealth when it comes without wisdom or virtue. Whereas, "Jay-Z" maybe hard pressed to agree, his sister in law is trying to knock him out in the elevator.

So, what you have here is a dichotomy that eventually gives up on itself and delivers the Robert Redford version verbatim for the last 30 minutes, giving you no reason to have ever mentioned Jay-Z or creepy pedophiliac new characters.

It sucked so hard, i think Leonardo is a demon... a really child-like demon with a penchant for sociopathy delivered through terrible movies. Every time he said "Ol' Sport," fingernails splintered on the chalkboard.

I wouldn't say I hope he dies, because I don't really give that much of a shi**, but, I will say I hope his character in his next movie dies because the aliens came back for their sh** and they don't need his body anymore.

title: Music
review: "The Great Gatsby" is an epic love story, not a party. While the main characters attended Gatsby's parties that were portrayed as illustrious and accurate to the time period, the parties were not the main point of the story. Gatsby used his parties not for the sheer amusement of hosting them, but in hope that Daisy would wonder in one night. The soundtrack of the movie missed the mark completely and is centered towards Gatsby's parties and the wild, elaborate life styles of the 1920s, rather than the love saga of Gatsby and Daisy. One song in particular that stood out was Fergie's "A Little Party Never Killed Nobody". Lurhman's "right hand man", Anton Monsted is quoted by the Hollywood Reporter saying, "It appears during the very same party scene as will.i.am's Bang Bang. It's one where we looked to create a song with very contemporary rhythms and beats, in conjunction with some period elements that remind us of the Jazz Age setting. And hopefully, again, in the final film, people will hear the weave between 1922 and 2013." (Trakin) While at times it has a hint of the 1920s, it is consist mainly of technology fabricated rhythms and rap sections. The premise of the song is focused on partying and depicts how Baz Lurhman wanted Gatsby to be represented. The irony is Gatsby did not even attend his parties; they were not for him or the guests, but instead for Daisy. The song simply does not go with what the story really is about nor does it add anything to the movie. Beyoncé and Andre 300 arranged a cover of Amy Winehouse's "Back to Black" specifically for the movie. First of all the song is completely irrelevant to the movie. The lyrics are disjointed from the story line and hold no significant meaning. Its purpose in "The Great Gatsby" is a mystery. Furthermore, it is painful to listen to and an overall poor reproduction. MTV criticized the arrangement of "Back to Black" saying, "All that remains are sparse wubs and synth cowbells, like a dubstep generator running out of gas, and a guitar line from a Nine Inch Nails deathscape. André comes corrupt, the villain of the piece, flipping Winehouse's words into audible taunts, pitch-shifted shrugs." (St. Asaph) The cover also has absolutely no indicators that would lead the listener to think the movie was a 1920s based setting; it is simply too modern. However, there were two songs that, while they were more modern than necessary, complimented "The Great Gatsby" and the main point of a love story. Lana Del Rey's "Young and Beautiful" is a love song. It is talking about a future with her lover and how she wants to be with him forever, even after death. Gatsby wanted to be with Daisy until died, and do everything in the world with her. Del Rey captures that love in a modern way that is appealing for the audience but also appropriate for the time period of the movie. The other song is Florence + The Machine's "Over the Love". The tone of the song is mournful, and morose. It talks about tearing a dress, crying, and doing other things over the love of someone that is unattainable. That is how Gatsby and Daisy's love is because they cannot repeat the past or be together. The song also mentions the green light that was the beacon of hope to Gatsby and his driving force for quite a while. The movie beings and ends with the green light and talks about its significance throughout the story. These two songs hold more relevance to the main point of the plot. Baz Lurhman intended for the songs of the 2013 adaption of "The Great Gatsby to have a twenty-first century twist and appeal to this generation of people. Similarly, F. Scott Fitzgerald incorporated the musical stylings of his era, jazz, however his book was based in that era; making the music choice less repulsive. Lurhman tried to merge his era with Fitzgerald's; but in the broad spectrum, he missed the mark completely. By focusing on the extravagant and illustrious life styles, parties, and affairs Lurhman deprived his viewers from the under laying story that was far more beautiful than was he portrayed on the screen. The music followed along with his plot and was distracting. Lurhman's attempt was in vain and his contributions were not acceptable to use in an American Classic.

title: I don't know what I expected...
review:
Baz Luhrman style is quite unique, in a bad way. I didn't like Romeo+Juliet or Moulin Rouge, but at least I could understand why other people would like those films. When I heard that he would direct a new version of "The Great Gatsby", I already had mixed feelings.

The main idea behind the story is that people like Daisy, Tom, Nick and Jordan are "old money" and have a sober, unexciting and monotonous life; but "Gatsby" is supposed a pretentious "new rich" who ends up being flamboyant, tacky and vulgar. Honestly, I thought that Luhrman was going to portray Gatsby's lifestyle like in Moulin Rouge and the others lives like a common film to make the contrast. However, the whole movie was over the top and extravagant. No homophobia intended, but this was probably the gayest mainstream film ever made. Characters like Daisy and Jordan seemed just as flamboyant as any other person at Gatsby's parties. This was probably mentioned a million times, but a movie of this genre shouldn't have this kind of editing. Not a single scene in the whole movie was static, there was movement and cuts every 3 seconds. I don't know what's the idea of spending so much in a film if you won't even let people enjoy the scenes.

On another point, I thought that all actors were great and talented. However... they didn't have the proper look. Dicaprio is obviously a handsome man, but he definitely doesn't look 32. Carey Mulligan is quite beautiful, but it is quite a shame that she didn't look that nice in the film; Elizabeth Debicki seemed much more beautiful than her as Jordan.

Finally, about the story itself, I think it is a shame that they just forgot about Jordan's character in the middle of the film. She just suddenly stops talking at some point. I also didn't like the fact that they took out the 2 of the most memorable parts of the novel: Jordan and Nick's break up (in the film it doesn't seem like they even break up) and when Nick finds Tom in New York again after all the events.

And well, I would like to say that this film was a big disappointment, but honestly, it was absolutely expected from Baz Luhrman to direct the film exactly like this. I don't even know what I expected... maybe I wanted him to redeem himself from all his other terrible films... but well, that's just too idealistic.

title: My rating: 7
review:
The Great Getsby. The embodied ideal, incapable to carry away the current in its waters. A man as a man, modest but with the great ability to believe and to hope that the balance of the world will bring back to him all that he personally gave. But he fails.

About the ability to make ideas real, to wait the exact moment, to be large-hearted, a gentleman. About the instinct to follow ideas, to count on old success, to be trivial, to forget.

Innovative staging, beautiful faces. This movie is successful and strong. It has his two hours and more. But we have seen his older version which was not aiming to modernize the story, to reach you with sound or with picture. It trusted on the true gentleman and his words which (specially for the people who love to seek and find) I have written somewhere else. It is interesting to make this parallel between this two movies(I can mention only one thing - Francis Ford Coppola). But only if you are inspired enough.

title: Voice over dominates the film
review:
First time I've felt compelled to review a movie, because I totally disagree with the very high ratings given to this movie so far. My complaint isn't about the movie being a hacked up version of the book, because almost all movies made from books involve compromise during the process of condensing a novel into a screenplay.

My issue with this movie is that is narrated all the way through with the actual movie just being a piece here and a piece there. I don't go to a theater to be told a story; I go there to watch a movie. The actors and actresses are great, but the way this screenplay was written and directed they have little opportunity to actually act. It is like an illustrated book, but the story is read to you and accompanied by snippets of video.

One might say that the use of narration is an artistic way to present the original book, but it is in my opinion taken to such an extreme it simply becomes a reading of a story rather than a movie.

title: Do Yourself a Favour and Go See It
review:
I almost didn't go see it the night it came out, boy was I wrong to think it isn't necessary. After seeing this movie I felt so inspired. When the lights came on the whole theater was in awe. We all felt a mutual unity. The scene was well set by the music and I really got the feeling of the 1920's. The illegal bars hidden from the eye, the colloquialism and the music mixes used to get the jazz feeling, all leading to a balanced and well planned movie.

Baz Luhrmann- the Director, really used all his knowledge and experience to produce "THE" movie of 2013 I am going to buy this DVD as soon as possible

title: While undeniably flawed, this film is not be totally dismissed
review:
First off, this is one of my favorite novels. I read it back in high school and haven't read it again since, so it's been around 15 years since I originally read it. I found myself mostly torn throughout the movie, so I definitely understand why it's been so polarizing for film critics. It almost impossible to write this spoiler free, so I eventually gave up. So here's my earlier SPOILER ALERT.

It's the roaring 1920s, the stock market is thriving and so is New York. A fairly unknown, yet highly publicized, wealthy man Jay Gatsby (Leonardo Dicaprio) appears seemingly out of nowhere in a wealthy Long Island suburb. He lives in a lavish mansion and throws wild, out of this world parties. Nick Carraway (Tobey McGuire), who's drawn to big city and the lifestyle of the elite, happens to move in right next door to him. Nick grows very curious of his new neighbor and is eventually invited to one of his parties where he meets Gatsby. He learns that Jay is interested in meeting his cousin, Daisy Buchanan (Carey Mulligan) who lives directly across the bay from Gatsby's mansion with her blue blooded, unfaithful husband Tom Buchanan (Joel Edgerton). Nick becomes emerged in Gatsby's world of nouveau riche and witnesses first hand Gatsby's hopeless optimism, larger than life persona, obsession and ultimately, his doom.

To talk about this film, I have to discuss it in halves. The first half of the film really brings the movie down. I found as the characters were introduced (outside of Nick) they were mostly over the top and really outlandish (almost laughably so). I also had issue with the soundtrack. I mean, it's the 1920s and it's set to Kanye and Jay-Z music? I mean really? It didn't make any sense to me at all as it didn't fit the era and made those scenes really bizarre. I get trying to modernize the film, but this was not the way to do it (and this is coming from a huge fan of both of those guys). Most of the time, the special effects were really subpar (the car driving scenes were really cartoonish) and 3D for the film was completely unnecessary and is a blatant cash grab. If there ever was a film that didn't need 3D, this was it.

Now for what the movie got right (the second half of the film mostly). I thought the film was really well paced. It certainly didn't feel like a 2.5 hour movie and there was plenty to keep you interested in the film. The costumes were very well done and captured the era well (compared to similar films of that era). At times the cinematography was incredible and really brought you into Gatsby's dream like world (the way the director captured Daisy's mansion across the bay and the green light was really well done and it reminded me of the novel).

I really loved Tobey McGuire as Nick Carraway! He always seems to have this quiet naivety in his roles and it was a perfect fit for Nick (another example that comes to mind in Keanu Reeves as Neo in The Matrix). In fact, I can't think of a better performance by Tobey and I hope he gets some recognition for this in awards season. Carey Mulligan gets Daisy about as well as you can, as a young woman who is completely oblivious to the real world and how her actions affect it. Joel Edgerton portrayed Tom adequately, I remember him being much more of a detestable person in the book (I thought this was the character that would've been really over the top). Dicaprio was good as Gatsby, but clearly not his best work. There's a deep sense of loneliness and longing for acceptance that personified Gatsby and outside of a few strong scenes, I felt he was a bit lacking there.

But most importantly, I think they got the story right and that's half the battle isn't it? As the major aspects of the plot unfold in the 2nd half, the characters are more believable, the events more meaningful and the film just gets better (mirroring the novel fairly well). As this point the story took over and the earlier flaws of the film seems less significant. The final scenes were gripping (I knew exactly what was coming) and were clearly the best part of the film. At the end of the film, I felt the novel was brought back to life (this is the main reason why I feel the film has been harshly dismissed by critics). I remembered just how detestable Daisy and Tom were. I remembered just how fake the people around him were and how sad it was that none of them came to say goodbye to him. The profound sense of remorse I felt for Gatsby when I read the novel, some fifteen years ago came flooding back and it affected me hours after I left the theater.

There are some important lessons in the novel that are still relevant even today. You can't change the past, no matter how much wealth, power and influence you obtain. And sometimes some things just aren't meant to be and no matter how hard you try to make it so, you can't change that. That is the great tragedy that is Gatsby; he was a character you admired, sympathized with and cheered for. But he was inevitably doomed because he couldn't let go of the past and his obsession drove him beyond reason. In this regard, the film was successful in my opinion. I'll conclude with my overall impression of the film (and the novel) by quoting Nick Carraway, because he illustrates this perfectly near the end of both the film and the novel:

"They're a rotten crowd... You're worth the whole damn bunch put together".

@the_move_snob

www.themoviesnob.ca

title: The Great Gatsby
review:
Movie: The Great Gatsby By: Baz Lumberman

Those years of the roaring 20's the flappers were something difficult to understand for the people who believed the past was really unexciting, who would thought that about 80 years ago people would be so alive and interesting. While watching the movie "The Great Gatsby" you can see how it portrays the way people lived in that era. Baz Lumberman did a great job making the movie as beautiful as the book itself. Very important to mention the music presented in the movie because it gives it a modern twist that makes the movie more interesting and fun to watch, because the music changes drastically the mood in the movie its gives it a more fun and pleasant mood.

The movie is set long island and it's divided between east egg, west egg and town, which are the 3 main places in which the movie focuses on. The story takes place during the 1920's. The main characters of the story are Jay Gatsby an amazing man, Daisy a beautiful women, Tom Buchanan a laying and mean person, and nick caraway and innocent and honest men. The story is about a man name Gatsby who has always been in love with beautiful women named daisy, when Gatsby is to leave to war for 5 years, daisy marries another man called Tom Buchanan a millionaire man who does not appreciate daisy as much as she should. When Gatsby comes back from war buys a huge house across the bay to have daisy near throwing huge party's every weekend waiting for her to show at one of his party's. Nick caraway Gatsby's neighbor is Daisy's cousin therefor Gatsby asks him to please help in bringing her for tea so that he can casually pass by and see her as much as he wants to. After they meet for the first time many feeling and memories are brought up

The main characters of the movie made a great job, they made it believable and that's what made the movie great. I wanted to remark DiCaprio's work due to the fact that he made an amazing job, we worked his paper really well and acted in a really good way, as in my opinion he was always been a great actor because he believes his paper and that is what maintains the movie interesting. The other characters as well did a great job, because every single one of them had the appropriate part of the movie. Therefor the casting itself to choose the characters was brilliant because they made a great job choosing them.

The whole movie was great and there is no part I hate about it, I may not have been convinced with the ending but that is up to my criteria but actually I would like to congratulate the movie because it's awesome it's a piece of art, a very good film of the book. It's a movie I'd love to see again because it's totally worth it. It truly convinces me and it may be in my top movies because it actually touches people feeling and changes people's point of view of that era's mood.

This movie left various lessons; such as chase your dreams because you may not know what will happen if you don't it. Is all about taking risks because it may lead you to something great. But in some way is good to know that you may try but you cannot pressure or ask for too much. Therefor the movie teaches too many important things especially Gatsby is the one who has more feeling you fights for his life and his love.

I believe it's a movie everyone could be allowed to see the movie, from all ages. I think kids should go with their parents, but it's a really good movie and it teaches many important things. While watching the movie and looking at the audience in the theater they are a lot of old people that want to watch a memory of their young life but it some it would be a shock to those old people because it's totally different way in which there era is portrayed. I recommend it to everyone who has the chance to see it. Even more too young people because I believe they would give more thought and they will enjoy it even more. It is a great movie; it brings up everyone's feelings in the way the characters relate to each other.

In my own opinion the movie is excellent and I would give it an excellent rating. A 90 and above would be the rating I would give it because in my personal opinion it is a piece of art. And amazing movie and the characters did a splendid work, making the movie real and making the receptor believe he is in the movie. Biography Her name is Paola Perez; she is a junior at Lincoln school in Costa Rica. The critique she wrote was a homework left by the Film appreciation teacher to learn how to critique and judge a movie by people's own criteria. She is 16 years old and she loves to do sports, watch movies in the cinema, and she loves to sleep and eat.

title: Stylish!...
review:
A film with some great set pieces; I found the party scenes particularly spectacular. It's beautifully shot and I'm quite glad I saw it in 2D as I couldn't see how 3D would have enhanced it much. I found the music interesting with the big set pieces being handed over to rapper Jay-Z (also an Executive Producer), but it was the original music by Craig Armstrong that I found most enthralling. There are several well known themes subtly placed in the soundtrack and I found both refreshing and interesting. All the performances were great with DiCaprio and Mulligan getting top billing; but I thought Tobey Maguire was equally good. I guess I'll have to read the book to be able to decide just how good an adaptation this is; but for now I found it quite a satisfying watch with plenty of drama to keep me entertained. If I was to be super critical I would have to say I found the character of Gatsby a little one- dimensional, but having said that it's still well worth a look if you get the chance.

SteelMonster's verdict: RECOMMENDED

My score: 7.5/10

You can find an expanded version of this review on my blog: Thoughts of a SteelMonster.

title: Cinematography at it's finest
review:
The Great Gatsby goes "all in". An example of great modern cinematography, re-telling a timeless story that has been told many times before yet now finally in an age where it's magnitude and glory can truly peak.

Visuals are absolutely mesmerizing to the finest detail,timed perfectly,delivered by some exquisite camera work and goose bumps giving shots,completed with suitable costumes and decor,bringing the "Charlestone" era to life with such good taste, accenting it's luxury without over doing it. What's also praise worthy is how they managed to make modern music work for that period of time. Lana del Rey, Gotye, Fergie, Will.I.Am and Jay-Z sure did light up the party!! - speaking of – party scenes choreographed an edited to it's finest – so well it leaves you wishing you were there cause them people knew how to have a good time,regardless their age.

As for the story – those who have red the novel say the film is quite authentic and follows the book nicely, even the dialogs. Film kicks off in a narrative form, it's first 20min or so being an introduction into a greatness that follows but you don't see it coming. Don't judge the whole film based on the beginning because it does come over a bit slow and I did have to remind myself that it is a DiCaprio film so it must be more to it than this. But it's purpose is to introduce the characters and set in the mystery around the great name Gatsby and relationships running under the water surface.

Personally I liked when narration was followed by letters on screen (although some found that detail tacky) – to me it fits in in the new modern look of the whole story and yet gives it kind of a fairy tale feel.

Baz Luhrmann like a pro builds it up from nothing, slowly allowing the viewer to get tangled in the glamorous net and let's you enjoy all the pageantry and pomp, filling your heart with music and laughter ( yes it was also funny) , making the key moments as spectacular as glorious fireworks itself, just so it would hurt all the more when the tragedy kicks in.

As for the cast – everybody delivers with such authenticity of emotions and character depth, it's absolutely mind blowing to watch their work unwind before your eyes.

Even the "small" characters like the organ player, butler, the mistress, the mechanic – surprise with the amount of presence they have in their scenes. Jason Clarke, small yet so important owns his scenes – like a first class actor would.

Carey Mulligan -this rising star is going places for sure!!! Well done young lady – well done!!! Gracious and innocent in her portray of Daisy she wins your heart from the moment she appears on screen only to brake it and leave it bleeding on a stone cold floor .

Tobey Maguire – got an opportunity that every actor that hides more in him than is able to show – dreams of!! Although he will never be the great gentleman (because of his boyish childlike appearance – even though he is DiCaprio's coeval) – as his sidekick he simply nails it. Calmness and warmth of his voice make him an excellent narrator. Naivety of his persona and goodness of heart make him the perfect toy for all 3 parties, as he tries to please and help – and yet he himself is much irrelevant to everybody. From the beginning till the end – he is a kind soul, his heart in the right place, tragically affected by the events that took place – and none of that would be the same has it not been for Tobey's charm – set in his eyes and warm smile. He gave this role all he head – and can stand proud and tall next to his friend  the one and only 

Leonardo DiCaprio!!!!! As much as the directing and editing had to do with his grand entrance in this film I can't think of anyone who would claim the moment they introduce Gatsby to the audience in a better way. He owns the camera, he owns the special effects – he owns YOU from the get go. This man as no other I have ever seen has the power to control me and my emotions by simply switching a look in his eyes. His tears water up my eyes, his joy puts a smile on my face. He doesn't play Gatsby – he IS Gatsby – and I don't think after him there will ever be anyone worthy of playing Gatsby again. Greatness of this actor goes beyond my words. He has that talent to bring a character to life and show you that persona in all it's layers with merely a look and a smile or a gesture. What he did with Gatsby is putting the rest of Hollywood to shame. A great gentleman, a business man, a romantic fool, scared boy dying to impress the love of his life, a crook, a raging animal, a man sick with obsession  a humble man with a dream determination and imagination like no other and most of all – strong enough will to never lose hope... He is one and only  and alone  with only one friend in this world that really cared for him - as the rest of the world was to consumed and corrupted with fear and urge to take the easy way out – in stead of fight or at least admire truly those who did.

The colors, the music, the shots and Leonardo DiCaprio made this film for what it is – painting of a sunset  Edgar Allan Poe's poem  and THE GREAT GATSBY made my night, my week – my month – reminding me why I love movies as much as I do.

title: The next-to-best Gatsby
review:
First, I want to say that I did not see the 3D version of this movie, so my review is only for the 2D version.

I read the book years ago. I saw the 1974 movie the year it came out. I am a fan of both. But I am also a fan of Baz Luhrman. One could tell this new movie was a Baz Luhrman product within 3 seconds. And the remainder of the film has his signature all over it. Even though I might criticize this 2013 version, I want to say that I liked it.

I preferred the music in the 1974 version, but I did not find the modern music of this version annoying at all. The 1974 film was slightly more faithful to the book--which is a good thing--but this version was fairly faithful. The main difference was the invention of a back story concerning Nick's health. I found it distracting and, more importantly, an invalidation of Nick's reliability as narrator (and our guide to the world of Gatsby and environs).

I also preferred the actors in the 1974 version. Redford is more reserved--a man in control, a man of mystery who does not wear his heart on his sleeve. Mia Farrow's Daisy was much more fleshed out and more believable, not to mention a sadder victim of her society. In similar ways, I preferred all of the acting choices from 1974.

Some have called The Great Gatsby a love story. From Gatsby's point of view, that is true. But from the reader's point of view, TGG is a mystery. As we read the book, we are trying to understand the man, and solve the mysteries of his past.

As others have said, the quick cuts that drive the narrative of the 2013 version are annoying and, worse yet, impair the viewer's ability to immerse himself in the lavish richness of the visuals.

One reviewer said she really enjoyed the "beautiful shirts" scene in the 2013 version. For me there was no comparison. I would use that scene as an example of where the 1974 film was much superior. When Redford tosses the shirts, the viewer feels he is in a rich, colorful, extravagant shower. And Farrow's Daisy is positively overcome by the experience.

In closing, I recommend this film, but I recommend that viewers first read the book and see the 1974 Gatsby. May you be lured to West Egg as surely as the jazz-age celebrants were drawn to the flame of Gatsby's determination.

title: Must See
review: The acting, writing, direction, and cinematography is phenomenal, and I believe it will be a classic for a long time. I loved every moment of this movie. Leonardo, Tobey and Carrie outdid themselves in their roles and suspended disbelief. As for the style of the music, I am in love with Lana Del Rey's "Young and Beautiful", it set the perfect mood for romance. A heads up, if you ever seen "Romeo and Juliet", "Moulin Rogue", some modern music is mixed into the movie even though it is a period piece, and I know some people tend to be put off when the classic is mixed with the modern, but Baz Luhrmann knows his stuff, and his choice of music is actually done very tastefully. As for his direction, LOVE IT!!!!!!Give yourself a treat, and if you are a F. Scott Fitzgerald fan, this movie did him proud. ~+~

title: Leonardo DiCaprio was a GREAT Great Gatsby
review:
LOVED IT! Leo was fabulous as Gatsby who starts as mysterious then slowly reveals his disillusions. I was expecting this director to give us over-the-top glamour and glitz... and it fit the 1920's. The scenes when Gatsby is revealing the past (e.g., when he is describing what he is thinking just before his first kiss with Daisy) - excellent.

Trivia: in the book, Daisy has dark hair and Jordan is blonde. In both the 1974 movie and this one, their hair colour is reversed. Generally, I would say don't change a thing that Fitzgerald wrote, but I have to admit, in my mind, Daisy is blonde, Joardan is a brunette.

What I did not like: Toby Maguire as Nick I did not think was a great fit. Some of the music. Listen to the soundtrack of the 1974 movie "what will I do..." evokes the feeling of lost love really well.

title: Magnificent Film, Beautiful Portrayal, Wonderful Cast and Visually Stunning!
review:
The Great Gatsby from Baz Luhrman is a truly magnificent film.

Tobey Maguire as Nick Carraway is absolutely wonderful, he does a great job narrating and has a wonderful calming presence throughout the movie. Leonardo gives an outstanding portrayal of Gatsby, not only does he portray the character as warm and likable, he shows us the underlining sensitivity and insecurity of Gatsby so perfectly. Both Tobey and Leo work beautifully in their scenes together, you sense a real bond that forms between the characters and the comedy that comes from the Tea for Daisy scene is highly entertaining. Carey Mulligan as Daisy was another wonderful performance, she portrayed her just as I had imagined from the book. All of these character's were actually portrayed to be likable and this really drew me in to the story.

The pacing of the movie was perfect, the music was used wonderfully! Always keeping it alive and bringing such an energy to the film. The production design was stunning! Though I would expect no less from a Baz Luhrman and Catherine Martin production, I was expecting great but really nothing can prepare you for what you see on screen. Visually it was beautiful and really took you away to this other world. This is easily my favourite movie within the last five years. It is Classy, Sophisticated, Warm, Funny, Dramatic and simply a wonderful entertaining film which I have to say I thoroughly enjoyed! I have read the book and seen the other movies and I have to say this was the most wonderful portrayal in my mind thus far, the most entertaining and very true to the book. Every page of the book that comes to life on screen was in my mind the absolute best Spectacular version of everything it could possibly be.

Thank you to Baz Luhrman and everyone involved for bringing this portrayal of the book to our screens. I thoroughly enjoyed it and have seen it twice already at the theatre, maybe I will even go again, and I can tell you I haven't felt this way about a movie in the past five years.

This movie has everything that seems to be missing from most films today, it contains almost no profanity, minimal violence and vulgarity, but focuses on Elegance, Class, Sophistication, Beautiful dialogue and drama, some humour, warmth, and just Visually Stunning, I encourage you to watch this film.

(I preferred to watch the film in 2D, so my comments are based on this viewing)

title: Gatsby makes for a forgettable movie
review:
Baz Luhrmann's The Great Gatsby is big, loud and lavish, more of an event than a film, and a substitution of essence for grandiosity. From the moment it was announced that the Australian filmmaker would adapt F. Scott's Fitzgerald's 1925 classic novel did we expect anything else? What Baz fails to cement is genuine purpose for his filmic style and the very reasoning for filming this story again. There have been three previous film adaptations, including a 1974 version with Robert Redford. The novel itself also possesses its own cinematic qualities, which further asks why it needed to be made into another film. Modernist writers, authors from the post-WWI period like Fitzgerald, T.S. Eliot and Faulkner, were influenced by the power of cinema in their work.

In his essay "T. S. Eliot and Cinema", David Trotter draws symmetry between the techniques of the written text and film: "The literary text, we are told, is structured like a film, in whole or in part: it has its "close-ups," its "tracks" and "pans," its cuts from one "shot" to another. Writers and film-makers were engaged, it would seem, in some kind of exchange of transferable narrative techniques". Trotter's essay reveals a broader question about why a novel needs to be adapted to film. Some film adaptations achieve heightened immediacy and atmosphere and expose more people to the source material. The producer of Gatsby, Douglas Wick, said that they wanted the story to be relevant to a new generation and make it less like a period film. Yet by utilising dizzying filmic techniques, including a superfluous 3D layer, Baz is selling a new generation a broader, faster but simplified version of this story that doesn't understand the novel's intentions.

As a filmmaker, Baz has fine technical knowledge but he never knows when to call cut. With his first film Strictly Ballroom, he showed careful selection in his direction, building a small, contained but hugely entertaining crowd pleaser. Now he is part of a Hollywood studio system where directors make their films increasingly more elaborate and grander so that they can sustain their own relevancy and bankability. His worst film Australia revealed his irrepressible kitchen sink syndrome by mixing jarring acting styles, dramatic and comedic tones and undisciplined cinematic choices. Despite drawing a rich, powerhouse cast for Gatsby including, Leonardo DiCaprio, Tobey Maguire, Carey Mulligan and Joel Edgerton, some of these erratic stylistic choices and habits come back to haunt Baz.

The first half of the movie feels rushed and hollow. Baz's primary technique is rapid cutting, so scene transitions and beats between set pieces become so frazzled that there is little time spent on substantiating the notion of old and new money - a core element of the novel. The camera movements are needlessly speedy, dipping and zooming wildly from the top of skyscrapers so that the few times they are allowed to pause is for a brief freeze-frame. Baz also treats the party scenes as though they are an elaborate music video, with bodies constantly in motion, as waiters and servants file into rooms with perfect synchronisation. This is all high kinetic movement but ultimately wasteful energy as these formal choices fail to connect themselves to a theme relating to class or materialism.

The soundtrack is also narrowly geared towards a younger demographic, instead of the authenticity of the Jazz Age or the novel's thematic core. Modern singers like Jay-Z and Beyonce are used in the film and the familiarity of their voices is distracting. In a crucial moment where Jay Gatsby (DiCaprio) prepares to reunite with Daisy Buchanan (Mulligan), a remix of Beyonce's song "Crazy in Love" plays over the vision of servants marching into the house together. It's a terribly directed scene that mistakenly treats Gatsby like a slapstick comedian. There is a lot of overstatement like this, particular when Nick Carraway (Maguire), who narrates the film through a voice-over, regurgitates observations already made clear by the camera.

The second half is mercifully slower, providing more time for the actors, but it fails to inject itself into the novel's thematic interests. DiCaprio suits the role of Gatsby because he gives the character a slick air of believable confidence and composure. There are some also gentle moments where he reveals an internal sense of longing through his face, without any intrusive flashbacks. Yet Baz's worst sin is that he buys into Gatsby's idealisation of Daisy. Their relationship is treated like a conventional sugary romance rather than a question of class or the social order. The casting of Daisy is problematic. Mulligan has been directed to play the part soppy, instead of darker, frivolous and superficial, so that the materialistic nature of her character is softened until the end.

Tobey Maguire seems uncertain on how to approach Nick because of his elusive characterisation and new material, including a thread where he is recovering from a breakdown and is told by a doctor to write the story out, does not have any emotional impact. Crucial female characters from the novel, including Jordan Baker (Elizabeth Debicki) and Myrtle Wilson (Isla Fisher), who is having an affair with Tom (Joel Edgerton), are also marginalised so that their importance barely registers. I hope Baz can rediscover his restraint as a filmmaker and remember that purpose and intent are the foundations of great storytelling and filmmaking so that his narratives can linger after the glitz and the technique have faded. Despite how lavish and busy it is, Gatsby makes for a forgettable movie - a label you couldn't even apply to Baz's worst efforts.
