This is two and a bit hours of my life that I won't get back. Very upsetting.

title: See it. Just see it!
review:
It has been a long time since I have written a review. But I felt like it was my responsibility as a movie-lover to advocate the brilliance of this beautiful film rendition to every other person I know.

Based on the 1925 novel, the 2013 version of The Great Gatsby kept me glued to the screen. There was actually a point during the movie when I had wanted to check the time on my watch but just couldn't look away. I should think one of the toughest parts of making such movies is having to capture the audience's attention, and making the audience appreciate what it was like to live in that era. But this film had effortlessly achieved that from the beginning, and brought that achievement to a whole new level. And that's coming from a guy who rarely appreciates films of such genre, what with it being set in the 1920s and all.

It has always been a wonder to me why DiCaprio hasn't gotten an Oscar for his work yet. He was (and still is) a brilliant actor who manages to live in the shoes of whatever role he plays. No exceptions here. Alongside the guy from Spiderman (I do know his name, don't worry), the duo charms the shoes off the audience while still playing their roles strongly and effortlessly. And I guess that's one of the elements that made the film so captivating.

And who didn't really fall in love with the beauty of Daisy, or the charm of Gatsby?

The artistic film had created an atmosphere that's so beautifully thick, yet one that's so easily digestible. Obviously long-winded for its own reasons, I never felt bored. I was, instead, eager for the story to keep going, even till the end. We loved Mr. Gatsby ever since he appeared in the film, in spite of the half-hour wait.

I could go on for hours, praising this movie for everything, but I should probably just... Stop typing, so you'd stop reading, shut your computer down, and buy a ticket.

title: A Great Movie, But Built Around a Trailer
review:
I'm a big fan of Baz, I'm a big fan of Jay-Z and I'm big fan of DiCaprio and Tobey in this movie, but something doesn't sit right when I watch this.

It's not a secret that this movie is visually captivating. The costumes, atmospheres and soundtrack all work together to make an alive, pastel delight. Simply put, it is fun.

To me it felt like all the elements were there. Obviously the plot line is solid, the acting is great and of course the visuals. Somewhere in the process of making this movie though, it feels like the overall direction was lost. There was a certain incongruity underneath it all.

For example the parties in the movie, as most will agree, are extravagant, but the emphasis put on them, and the general bravado of the film almost seem like the centre-piece with the storyline, and character development tacked on top. I didn't feel engaged on a human level. It seemed to me that every line from the trailer was over pronounced in the actual film, which not only made me think that the trailer was over hyping, but also that the film was made with the trailer in mind, which makes sense considering the lack of focus and direction.

Overall this movie was fun and had a certain wow-factor that makes it worth seeing in 3D, but there was an overpowering sense of the whole thing being stitched together, without having someone smooth out the overall shape to something that made sense through and through.

But of course, this is just my opinion. Many of my friends loved this film, and I'm sure many more will too.

Enjoy!

title: The Great Gatsby - a great story
review: This is a movie worth watching. Unlike the majority of junk produced by Hollywood, which are time wasters. This is a great story and the movie makes it flashing. Good job to the producers, good taste!. I loved the dresses, the parties, the customs, the suits, the elegance, the shine and splendor of the material world, even the coal town, and mostly loved Gatsby's passion, his tragedy, his despair, his longing, his hope. Leonardo Di Caprio is such a handsome man. Can I have a man who can love me as much as he did Daisy? And if he looks as handsome even better! lol Five start!!!! Go watch this movie!!! It shows so much about the human character, that it made me even question myself - am I careless? Do I just walk around destroying people and things? I loved the scene where Gatsby is waiting for Daisy and then he runs away, his poor heart couldn't contain the emotion, for a second fear almost won, but then he comes back and well, it just melts my iceberg.

title: Not that bad at all
review:
Any movie by Australian director Baz Luhrmann is worth seeing because he has such a distinctive and exuberant style and you have to admire his willingness to be different, even if he is - as the "Guardian" film critic Peter Bradshaw put it - "a man who can't see a nuance without calling security for it to be thrown off his set". In different ways, I enjoyed "Moulin Rouge" and "Australia" and I was prepared to give "The Great Gatsby" a go, in spite of some harsh reviews.

The F Scott Fitzgerald novel of 1925 has been filmed no less than four times before, notably in 1974 when Robert Redford played the plutocrat Jay Gatsby and Mia Farrow was his great love Daisy Buchanan in a restrained interpretation. Of course, Luhrmann does not do restraint and, in this movie, as well as his trademark grandiose sets and extensive CGI, he has shot the work in 3D, but I can only take so much Bazz and for this jazz I chose to see a 2D version, although even then it is very obvious where the 3D was intended to hit you in the eyes.

It is, of course, over the top (most obviously in those huge party scenes in the Gatsby mansion), the framing device of Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire) in a sanatorium is unnecessary, and the use of non- contemporary music by the likes of Jay-Z often jars. But there are some lavish sets and some gorgeous costumes and the whole thing has undeniable energy. Leonardo di Caprio has both the charm and the menace of Gatsby, while Cary Mulligan as Daisy continues to grown as an international star. Not so much "All that Bazz" as "Not that bad".

title: No summary
review: There is no way all luhrmann's pyrotechnic glamour can match up the poetry of the book. Apparently The Great Gatsby is one of those books that no matter how accurate the movie is, (which it is) can't compare to the ABSOLUTE beauty and profoundness of the book. Its imagery, the character's complexities, did not transcribe. There is hardly any dialogue in the book and that is also the beauty of it. But obviously a blockbuster movie can't base a whole movie just on looks and words unspoken. It needs a story and all those unnecessary conversation have to take place for an average audience to understand the plot. So it just goes down to this compromise, while you are fascinated by Luhrmann's scenography, you are left with nothing for the brain to think on and you might just assume it's one of the other thousand of ordinary movies on corrupt marriages of the upper class. There is no way the movie portrays Gatsby's Greatness. But again, it's nobody's fault. Just some books of a certain caliber should be left books.

title: I Loved It.
review:
I wasn't so sure when going in. I think Lurhman has a lot of skill bot not always the best focus.

That is to say that often he uses strong technique but in a way that makes a scene about the technique more than the story.

His films have always been likable but not totally fulfilling for that reason.

The Great Gatsby however as lush and as beautiful as it was was done in a way that the visual style and technique always serves the story. Never just calling attention to itself.

I go to the movies a lot and this is really one of the best films I have seen in a long time.

A masterpiece? Absolutely.

title: Big Mistake
review:
I have a complaint about this movie.

I felt so bad watching this movie. The movie went on and on and on but it was missing something...Alicia. There was no Alicia at this movie, and that is all my fault. I wanted an Alicia, of course. But due to my stupidity and carelessness....

You see, Alicia would have made the movie Grand! She would have laughed when they played Jay-Z songs, she would have made fun of Toby McGuire's mouth, we could have sneered about how not-pretty Daisy was, and we could have exchanged comments about how goddamn old Leo is. But I forgot...

But it won't happen again! I will make sure of that!!

Also, the acting was nice, but the scenes and such were a bit much.

title: Why
review:
Leonardo was perfect for this role. Tobey McGuire was also great. It was well cast until they get to the important roll of Daisy.

Why? why? WHY? would you pick a plain Jane, crooked mouthed, pug nose, dull personality like Carey mulligan to play the part of daisy? Daisy is supposed to be so incredible that she could make a man like Leonardo DiCaprio so obsessed that he can never put her out of his mind? It just does not make any sense!

I could not for one minute imagine her as Daisy. It just ruined the whole film for me.

They really dropped the ball on this one.

title: Luhrman's worst film
review: I've been a long time fan of Mr. Luhrman. Strictly Balloom, William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and Austrilaia are amongst my favorite films. And Moulin Rouge is my favorite film of all time. I enjoy it's manic creative intensity that gives his films a memorable original flair not seen in any other films. So it is with sadness that I say that The Great Gatsby is a huge disappointment. The combination of modern day music and Luhrman's visual dazzle may have sounded like a good idea on paper but it makes the film feel disjointed and unrelatable. Although I'm not too familiar with the source material I'm assuming shadings of it come through but overall I'm not sure anything much comes through at all. The film starts out chaotically enough like Moulin Rouge (a little too simlar in fact) but than it begins to settle and there is a moment when you think Oh this a love story and than the focus strays away and we are left confused again. The performances are decent with a few too many unintentionally funny moments. these are fine actors here just not in their best form. As for the films visuals they are indeed stunning but feel unnecessary in translating such a storyline. And well the direction feels a little directionless the party scenes are fun but nothing seems to be going anywhere or amounting to much. the hyper intensity displayed throughout the film doesn't fit the proceedings at all constantly leaving you feeling a little bored with a stunted sense of empty awe. This is without a doubt Luhrman's worst film. That being said it's not a horrible film there is still some stuff to see here the modern soundtrack is electrifying if not fitting. The party scenes and cinematography although unnecessary are wondorous. I'm not sure when he started to disconnect with the material but I'm willing to forgive this little blip on his resume in hopes that he will get back to his more traditional, original faire. 2.5/5

title: A Beautiful Film that Lacks Emotion
review:
So a dramatic film, from the director of "Moulin Rouge" and "Romeo + Juliet" marketed as a visual spectacle, shot in 3D; what could possibly go wrong?

Based on F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel of the same name, "The Great Gatsby" focuses on, not Jay Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio), but rather the times that his neighbor, Nick Carraway, (Tobey Maguire) spent with him during the roaring twenties.

So this is one of those very hit or miss movies. As someone who has never read the book, I really can't make comparisons so I can only judge it as a movie. I'll start with the negatives, because I feel that the movie missed more points than it hit. First, a positive, this is a very beautiful movie to look at. It's so visually beautiful that it seems to take away from the story and becomes a distraction. I didn't see this movie in 3D, but I have a feeling the 3D wouldn't have made a difference, despite being a visual spectacle, it are aren't a lot of visual scenes, which I feel may have led to some useless 3D. I found the music very distracting. Sometimes they would play music that was relevant for the time period this movie take play, but other times they would play hip hop music or other popular songs relevant for the 21st century. I seriously expected "Gangnam Style" to play at some point. It would've made as much sense as featuring JAY Z or Beyonce and Andre 3000 in the movie.

Now this movie isn't all bad, because this movie did get many things right. Even though the visual style distracts form the story, it is incredible to look and there was never a dull moment though out the entire movie. The performances were also great, I haven't seen Tobey Maguire in anything after he finished the Spider-Man Trilogy, but he managed to break away from the awkward nerd that he was known for in "Spider-Man". Even though Carrey Mulligan was good, in nearly every scene she's in, it looks like she's on the verge of tears. Obviously the star of the movie is Leonardo DiCaprio as Gatsby. Who am I going to have to beat up in order to insure that this man gets an Oscar? Not for this movie, but this role does continue to show how great of an actor Leo is.

Overall it's not a mess of a film, but it definitely could've had some major improvements, but what it got right, it got really right. I feel that it's one of those movies where you make up your own mind about it. If you feel that it's for you, you might like it. If not, then you can either avoid it or wait for it to come out on Blu-ray.

title: The Pure Brilliance of Gatsby!
review: The simplicity of the story is what draw's people to the book (well English teacher's force the book on students), but what they should force is this adaptation of the film. Di'Caprio's "Gatsby" is purely fascinating, with Leo's look on the man who came from nothing and made himself someone for that ONE girl. Tobey's performance is like none before, he is the man that was invited into a new world, but never knew what he was actually being invited too. Enough about the actor's, the cinematography; in the same bigger than the world should allow party's and wardrobe (not to mention soundtrack) is just as amazing as it can be. Yes you need to be a fan of the book to enjoy the movie's story, but you can be amazed simply if you watch the acting and scenery. Its a MUST go!!

title: Gatsby was a grand Tour De Force
review: It wasn't just a movie, it was an experience. All 50 of us movie goers were entrenched, immersed even in this 3D experience for 2.5 hours. Ignore the supercilious reviews and watch this cinematic masterpiece for yourself and decide. Great Gatsby WAS great! It was wistful, poignant, visually stunning, superbly executed, had amazing actors, florid detail which was mesmerizing at times, had a beautiful story line and allowed you (even if for a brief while) to get into Gatsby's head and feel what it is like to love someone so much that it's almost an obsession which rules your life. admittedly I have never read the book, however, I could definitely relate to his sheer devotion to Daisy which encapsulated half a decade of his life. Leonardo Di Caprio was the PERFECT fit for the role. I might be partial because I have loved him since BasketBall Diaries and think that he is an amazing actor. When you can convey words and emotion with your eyes THAT is when you know its good acting. There was a lot of silent cues like that in this movie which kind of tugged at your heartstrings. I really don't understand the negative reviews, it is based on a fictional book and yes there is flamboyance in some parts however that was also true of the excess of the time period. Not much to over think here. If you want to be entertained for a little over 2 hours and are not pedantic SEE THIS MOVIE!

title: I came to Scoff
review:
I came prepared to scoff. I expected an over-the-top razzle dazzle Gatsby story after the previews I saw-in 3D yet. In fact, this was as good a filming of this classic book as has yet been done, and I believe, as good as can possible be done. There is a line in "The Last Tycoon" which says "you can't film great prose", but it is actually and literally done here.

This film starts out with a tongue in cheek style. The performers are doing comic book versions of their characters, but the plot continues and the movie gets quite serious and eventually even somber. This follows the emotional tone of the novel. As course there are differences between the novel and the film, primarily with the more subtle nuances of the novel, but this is a movie and subtlety doesn't work too well in big screen 3D spectaculars

BTW, Elizabeth Debicki as Jordan Baker steals every scene she is in, even when she has no lines.

Go see it. If you are a "Gatsby" purist, you won't be disappointed.

title: THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) ~ 10/10*s ~ a criminally underrated picture; a perfect adaptation of Fitzgerald's classic novel
review:
The Great Gatsby 2013 Dir.: Baz Luhrmann Starring: Leonardo DiCaprio, Tobey Maguire, Carey Mulligan, Joel Edgerton

10 *s out of 10

Okay .. the masses are often ignorant and enjoy complaining .. and many lay-folk, who have read the novel seventy-five times (rightfully so), then want nothing more than everything they've ever envisioned in their heads and hearts to be on the silver screen when the time comes for the big-screen version .. but adaptations can never follow the imaginary, idiosyncratic guidelines of millions and millions of readers of a great novel over the decades .. this 2013 film here, in context, or maybe even outside of any context, is as good as it gets for being an adaptation of a classic American masterpiece as towering as Fitzgerald's best work, and, on its own, it's a perfectly-nailed period-drama ..... trust me .. time will show that this IS magical stuff .. this DOES work with all of its successes, including one of the better casts of the past few years .. and, btw, Tobey Maguire is a damn perfect Nick Caraway!; I don't care what regular folk and/or critics say - it IS a nuanced performance, and a damn fine one in every way, shape and form ..... this is a gorgeous film, and as well-shot as you've heard; as well-acted as you've heard; as well-written as can be .... and, contrary to what SOME of the critics were saying, there is actually a lot of the essence of the Fitzgerald novel well-infused throughout this modern gem .. The Great Gatsby (2013) is electric!

10 *s out of 10

title: A faithful, beautiful retelling of Fitzgerald's novel
review: This movie completely took me by surprise. I have a love for F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel, and I was a bit skeptical about how the book would translate to the silver screen. But I can honestly say that The Great Gatsby was one of the most faithful book-to-film adaptations that I have ever seen. Luhrmann remained true to the book down to the colors of the character's clothing.The soundtrack was beautiful, the CGI and the costumes were gorgeous, the script was impeccable, and the casting was very smart. At first, I thought that Leonardo DiCaprio was nothing more than a heartthrob, a way to sell tickets. This movie changed my mind about him. Now, I consider Leonardo to be one of the greatest actors of our generation. He brought an edge to Gatsby's character as well as maintaining his sense of unwavering hope and his undying love for Daisy Buchanan. He played the character flawlessly. He was Gatsby. Now to review Carey Mulligan as Daisy. There is no doubt that Mia Farrow had the delicate beauty of Daisy, but Farrow portrayed Daisy as very ditzy. Carey Mulligan gave Daisy a backbone. She gave the character depth while still giving her a sense of naivetÃ© and girlishness. Before Gatsby, I had never seen Tobey Maguire in a movie. I thought he embodied the troubled character of Nick excellently while making him very lovable. Maguire made me love Nick's character even more. I hadn't seen Joel Edgerton in a movie either. But I thought he was the absolute perfect Tom Buchanan. Bruce Dern was a fine Tom, but he made him nothing more than a bigoted jerk. Edgerton brought more to the role, making Tom's objectives rational, and by giving him more dimensions than just racist and nasty. So in conclusion, thank you Baz Luhrmann. You brought the book to life in a way that I never imagined.

title: Overall a great achievement on a great but difficult book
review:
I suppose, in most cases, whenever a beloved American classic is adapted to the screen there will be contention on the merits of the film. In Baz Luhrmann's vision of "The Great Gatsby" there appears to be even more criticism probably due to the fact that there have been many other film versions and because the book is so beloved by so many. It is difficult for people to not compare and contrast this film and in the process become overly critical. However, Luhrmann's rendition of "The Great Gatsby" really works and everything from the vividness of the set design, to the weaving of Fitzgerald's prose into the film, to the performances of the cast, was adeptly executed.

I was impressed by Luhrmann's adaptation of Fitzgerald's iconic work of literature. For the most part, all of Fitzgerald's major themes are compellingly and stylishly represented: The rich and nouveau riche are all shown with the over-the-top excesses of the "haves" and aptly juxtaposed with the "have-nots" who are decent people trying to survive; The discrimination and feeling of contempt by those who were bred in a privileged society as opposed to those who newly acquired their wealth; The inability to extricate oneself from the past and to understand the nature of true love; How those with the most hide behind their fortune and could care less about the rest of society including those who work for them. All these major themes are clearly represented in the film and hammered home by the solid performances of the actors.

Because the film, by and large, was faithful to Fitzgerald's work the themes that were explored in the book remain intact in the film. This film is an instant classic because it did not diverge too far from the classic it was based on. Although Fitzgerald's book was written in the 1920's we see the rich in our society pretty much act the same way today. After all, few can argue that the financial collapse that hit our economy within the past five years was not in large part due to the "carelessness" of the rich who promulgated the reckless borrowing while at the same time hedging their bets against those that borrowed. There are still those in the wealthy segments of our society that can afford to be careless precisely because they are rich and their wealth was often begotten by that very carelessness of others. Luhrmann's film accurately reiterates this theme and other themes because it stayed true to Fitzgerald's vision of America.

"The Great Gatsby" is an excellent film because it accurately captures the themes of the original author, and is as relevant today as it will be in the future.

title: Stays with you
review:
I have to admit, when I watched the movie I didn't feel as attracted by it as I do now. But it grew on me, because I kept thinking about it and how it was done. And it's the first movie that Baz Luhrman did that really achieved that with me. It's only the 4th I've seen, but still something to cherish upon. The music would also be something you could cherish upon.

Though I'm not sure if that also could be something that takes you out of it completely. While this is a period piece, the music is very modern indeed. It takes a bit to get used to that. Though the dance moves are clearly from that time, which goes to show you, that dance styles may differ, but the music could be different too and the styles would still be intact.

But while music is always a big part of a Luhrman movie (as are the sets they are shot on, impressive as always), it is the story that is compelling. Almost as compelling as the main female character is to Gatsby himself. There are quite a few character flaws but also a depth to them, that might be rare to other Luhrman movies. I really liked where this was going and the movie is really good too.

title: A little over the top and music didn't always fit, but all in all still great.
review: Most scenes in the film are very well transformed from the book. The delayed mysterious introduction of Gatsby and his reunion with Daisy is just heartwarming. The music, especially in the first half of the film (up to Lana Del Ray), did not fit. Jay-Z and Alicia Keys? Modern beats nibbled on the credibility. The fact that the music did not come from the band playing in the scenes took away the feeling of actually being there. Visually, it did not fall short, somewhat over the top. The 3D was subtle, precisely enough to support the extravagant scenes and extreme camera work. I expected some tears to roll, but the story didn't pickup the way I expected it to. Some scenes were not true enough to the book. The scene with Tom and his mistress was vulgar and unnecessary. Apart from these critical points, the cast surprised me. Di Caprio great as Gatsby. Great as always; he delivers. I was skeptical of Maguire and Mulligan. However, they both surprised me in their own way. Mulligan was a natural beauty in appearance and character. Together with her reserved nature, displayed a very well rounded personality. Maguire narrated the story nicely and showed he could carry the story. He showed he is more than a wall crawler. A must see? With a little hesitation, yes.

title: The Great Gatsby may be flashy and full of grandeur, but ultimately it falls short when it comes to heart and substance.
review:
he Great Gatsby. Directed by Baz Luhrmann. Based on the novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Starring Leonardo Dicaprio, Carey Mulligan, and Tobey Maguire. Rated PG-13 with a running time of 143 Minutes. Given a 7.5/10 on IMDb.com and certified 48% Rotten on Rottentomatoes.com

"A Midwestern war veteran finds himself drawn to the past and lifestyle of his millionaire neighbor."

So I've read "The Great Gatsby" in my current English class and I've found that I thoroughly enjoy the story but I don't really like the book or the 1974 movie. However, I attempted to watch this film with an open mind, from the point of view of an average movie goer, with no prior knowledge of Gatsby and here's what I took from the film overall.

Luhrmann delivers as always with a dreamlike beauty on the side of cinematography. Each scene is beautifully sculpted, flashy, and absolutely magnificent. However, the vast amounts of green screen used to create these scenes tends to be too "in your face" for my taste and I eventually got so tired of it to the point that I was getting a headache. I can't imagine the pain that anyone watching in 3D was feeling. That being said, the visuals on this film are definitely worth the $10 I dropped to watch it.

The cast did a phenomenal job with their characters. Carey Mulligan who plays Daisy Buchanan gave just enough flair and melancholia to her character to be admired. Tobey Maguire sadly fell short in a role that's absolutely important to the plot but ultimately so simple that anyone could've pulled it off, which is what saddens me considering Maguire is a capable actor but it seems he just missed it on this role. Leonardo Dicaprio's Jay Gatsby is honestly the best part of this film. He truly embodies all of the complexities of Gatsby is a way that's never been done before and I'd argue that this is, if not one of, his greatest performances of his entire career. However, try as they might, the phenomenal acting just isn't enough to the film out of the water.

The first half of the film is full of grandeur and tantalizing imagery, but the Kanye West soundtrack and lack of any 'real' plot development left me bored and disappointed. Sadly, I wanted to leave the theater in within the first thirty minutes. About midway, when Daisy and Gatsby meet, the film does get better but at this point it just isn't enough. There's an immense amount of overacting, weird shots, and a level of silliness that just can't be shaken. Nick Carraway's constant narration becomes annoying. I found myself on the edge of my seat as the film spiraled into it's climactic conclusion, spinning a beautiful end, but it was too difficult for me not to laugh at how hard they were trying to pick something up after it had dropped and shattered upon the floor. I had to check my watch multiple times in the cinema and I was relieved by the time the credits finally began to roll.

Overall, The Great Gatsby had entirely too much potential to be absolutely incredible and a spectacular rendition of it's source material, but it fails to capture the true heart and meaning of the book. It weaves a carnival of wonder and I really wanted to love this film. It's not a disaster, but by the time it decides what it's doing, it's already too late. I suggest it's better to "beat on" then to waste your time. Sorry, Old Sport.

I'll see you at the movies!

~Tyler Skye Gordon

title: This Was a Film I Could Not Crack
review:
A Review of The Great Gatsby

It is sometime after midnight as I write this. My head is still pounding due to the three dimensional glasses I wore when watching the 2 and a half hour long The Great Gatsby. If someone were to ask me right now: what did you think of the movie? I would be unable to answer in speech. The only way to convey my opinion of this movie is through text, precisely what I am doing here. The story centers on the mysterious Jay Gatsby (Leonardo Dicaprio), a self-made millionaire with a questionable past, and his relentless pursuit for the love of his life Daisy Bucannan (Carrey Mulligan). The movie was based on F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel that was published in 1925. The Great Gatsby was a movie unlike anything I had watched before. As I left the movie theatre, I couldn't crack it. The film itself, with all its technical aspects and star-studded cast, is excellent. Dicaprio gives a stunning performance as Gatsby from the minute we first meet him. If there is anyone living today that could evoke the kind of confidence and hope that Gatsby possesses, it's Dicaprio. As for Carrey Mulligan, the only adjective I can use to describe the effect her performance has on the movie watchers is breathtaking. She is Daisy. The sweet, innocent, self-sheltering girl from the novel comes to life on screen thanks to Mulligan's acting ability. Yet, there is one character that shares in this spotlight, Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire). Throughout the entire film, Nick seems to be the only character sober enough for us to latch on to. He guides us through the craziness of the 1920's and does a fantastic job executing the narrator style. Further enhancing the film's allure is the time period, the location, and the ability of director Baz Luhrmann to bring the reality of it all to the screen. For those of you that have studied up your history on the 1920's, you know what a crazy time period it was. As Nick comments in the film, "the buildings were higher, the morals were looser, and we all drank too much." Luhrmann paints the 1920's across the screen throughout the entire film. The only thing that stuck out like a sore thumb was the choice of modern hip-hop/rock/music for the soundtrack. However, I found myself gasping in certain scenes because there is just so much to take in at once. In fact, the first half of the movie feels like one long, crazy 1920's party.

However, what truly shocked me was the ability for the novel to be placed on screen so fully. I've seen quite a few movies that originated from books, and they all seem to leave huge chunks of the plot out. Not this movie. This film is by far the best novel to movie transition I've ever seen. The themes that are present in the book (the ones we all studied in English class) are present throughout the crazy journey you take with Gatsby. So if you're one of those people who think the movie will never be as good as the paper form of the story, this one might change your mind. And another thing, even if you have read the book, you will leave the theatre with a deeper understanding of the story, perhaps deeper than you wanted. It's one thing to read about the corruption, carelessness, and downfalls of the characters, but it's another thing to actually see those things. I was pleasantly surprised overall. I had seen Baz Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet and I did not enjoy it. But thanks to Dicaprio's and Mulligan's amazing performances and the whirlwind scenes that dot the movie, I give it two thumbs up. My advice, go out and see it as soon as you possibly can.

Rating Warning: Rated PG-13 for some violent images, sexual content, smoking, partying and brief language.

I give it 7 out of 10.

title: Don't believe the hype.
review:
Disregard all the hype about how the director couldn't really pull this off, that the spectacular style doesn't fit the story, or that the music is all wrong, etc.

I think this is one of the best movies I've ever seen. The 3-D technique captured an astonishing feeling of depth and realism. The acting was powerful and impressive. The character of Nick was given due respect of weight and authority. The story-telling gradually took on a very beautiful visual poetry. The climax and ending had me with jaw a-drop and tears welling up.

Do see it in 3-D and do see it as soon as you can. My wife, a teacher, treasures the book and was very on guard for a disappointment. She couldn't go so I saw it alone and now I've told her she must come with me to see it again.

title: A Movie...Not a Book...
review:
As my title says, this is a movie and not a book. If you want this movie to be drawn-out, slow, thematic, and dramatic, then your in the wrong place. That stuff doesn't sell movies these days.

With that being said, I did not feel that the movie was too over-the-top or far off from the book. I was actually scared going into the movie because I thought it was going to be dreadfully slow and dramatic. Also the terrible CGI in the trailers did not help. However, the movie got on my good side pretty quickly. The director was very in tune with what the majority of people want from a movie about The Great Gatsby. He made the entire movie a memory of Nick Carraway's. That was a brilliant idea because it allowed for the crappy CGI, rapid pace, and sometimes questionable soundtrack to fall under the, "its just how he remembers it" idea.

The book was terribly slow. This movie is quick and it includes a lot of stuff. People say it is all flash over substance, but if they can't see the substance then they weren't looking. It is supposed to be flashy! Its the Roaring Twenties! The spectacle was perfect to give the viewer a sign of the times.

The acting was awesome! I thought that they had Carraway and Gatsby casted perfectly as Toby McGuire and Leonardo DiCaprio going into the movie, but what I didn't see coming was Buchanan! I think the actors name is Edgerton or something like that, but that dude did an awesome job in this movie. It seems like every actor was in-tune with their character. Thank goodness DiCaprio understood Gatsby. He seems like such a manipulator in the book sometimes; however the movie gives him a more human-element and the viewer can see that he is many things.

I will have to admit, going in I was scared that this movie was going to be a total flop. The CGI scared me, Jay-Z always scares me, and the fact that it was a movie about a insanely dramatic book scared me. However, at the end of the movie I felt like I understood the novel better than I ever had before. Was it a bit over the top in places? yes. Did it play too much on some themes and not others? yes. Did it follow the book exactly? no. But it is a book that people love and when that is the case no movie adaptation can ever be correct. I feel that this movie did a tremendous job of staying true to the book, the setting, the themes, the characters, and the tragedy.

This is definitely a must see.

title: Seductively entertaining and visually magnificent.
review:
Watching this film requires a few concessions.

First, you must imagine the elegantly beautiful 1974 classic version does not exist. Trust me. It's painful otherwise, and I will avoid any reference or comparison for that reason. Second, you must also imagine that, notwithstanding Fitzgerald's masterpiece, the setting is not the Roaring Twenties but, rather, some over amped time warp netherworld where Jay-Z and Beyonce' get to be avant garde again because they're rather incongruously and anachronistically foisted on a film in which they really have no place.

If you make it that far, you're almost ready to watch The Great Gatsby 2013. Now brace yourself for Baz Lurhrmann's jarring postmodern deconstructivism that was thrilling a decade ago in Moulin Rouge, but has become by now almost as grotesque as Julie Taymor's murderous affront to Beatle music – Across the Universe.

Thus prepared, you can now enjoy what is undeniably an entertaining, if uninspiring, film.

Tobey Maquire, of whom I am usually a fan, is somewhat flaccid as Nick Carroway, despite the fact that the story depends utterly upon him to drive it forward. He does, however, bring a decidedly literary dimension to the film by framing the main story within his own attempt at recovery. Joel Edgerton is a perfectly delightful Tom Buchanan. He embodies all the machismo brutishness with which Fitzgerald envisioned the character. He also has enough personal charisma to help anchor the otherwise riotous staging. And, of course, there is DiCaprio as Gatsby. I didn't hate him, although I was predisposed to, but I wanted to love this movie, and Leo was one of the main reasons I couldn't.

As far as casting, however, the jewel of this film is the deliriously sensuous and beautiful Carey Mulligan as Daisy Buchanan. She makes it easy to believe that Daisy broke hearts with just a smile back in Louisville and inspired Gatsby to bring the world to her dock for her sake.

This film mines Fitzgerald's novel for more complex themes than predecessors have explored. Sometimes it works, and sometimes it doesn't. Ironically, it also strips all the novel's major themes of any subtlety whatsoever and reduces them to stage settings for an unrelenting onslaught of elaborate music videos.

But if I reel in my disappointment for a moment, I can only conclude that this is a well-made movie that is seductively entertaining and visually magnificent. Maybe it isn't fair to expect more.

title: Okay movie that could of been great
review: many of u guys like me had huge expectations after hearing the cast and watching the trailer. I love Decaprio, i love Tobey Maguire, heck i love the music in this movie. Its starts off exciting and entertaining. But this movie has no substance. It isn't a terrible movie but i hated how fast this director made romeo and Juliet (and also how weird it was), he also made this movie fast paced, it was on roid rage. Some people who want to see a fast pace story with music and party's will love it. But it doesn't get any deeper than that. Its probably more exciting than the book but it doesn't include the deep substance that it deserves. But overall it was a okay movie that could of been better.

title: A Ravishingly Beautiful and Highly Entertaining Film
review:
I very much liked Baz Luhrmann's version of The Great Gatsby. I would have been disappointed if it had not been filled with striking visual images of beautiful people but it was filled with many of both. I have long been fond of F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel of the same name and this is the first film version of the story I have seen that I thought worked. Much of the dialog was from Fitzgerald's own words.

The large ensemble cast was excellent. I was particularly impressed with the performances of Tobey Maguire, as Nick Carraway, and Joel Edgerton, as Tom Buchanan. As usual, Leonardo DiCaprio was excellent, this time as Jay Gatsby.

Luhrmann has achieved another artistic triumph. Highly recommended! 8 Stars out of 10.

title: A Visualized Novel (Minor Spoilers)
review:
When I first heard about writer/director Luhrman's return to film; I was actually pretty excited; his visual thrills and his mixing of modern pop culture and period drama made Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge two of the most aesthetically memorable films ever. However, Many people reasonably questioned his ability to bring F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby; one of the biggest novels of all time to the big screen. The book put more of an emphasis on character drama and conflicts in society than artistic grandeur. Having just seen it, I can honestly say that his direction was as much of a success as it was a problem.

The film centers around Nick Carroway (Played by Toby Macguire of Spiderman and Brothers), a former writer, telling the story of how he met the infamous Jay Gatsby (Played by Leonardo DiCaprio- see below); a small town man who turned his life of low income and misery into a wealthy life of parties and liquor. Throughout the film, Nick gets caught in the middle of a series of scandals including his married cousin Daisy (Played by Carrey Mulligan of An Education) and Gatsby's secret romance. What follows is a slew of chaotic events that could destroy everyone and everything including Nick, who didn't want any part of it.

As one can imagine, this film about the roaring 20's contains a lot of drama, betrayal, lust and intensity. All of these elements ad more are expressed through the film's use of colorful sets and costumes as well as its refreshing use of modern music from artists like Jay-Z and Lana Del Rey. All of these qualities really enhance the story and Luhrman's vision of the classic tale is quite admirable. From the sleek custom cars to the sparkling flapper outfits, there is always something gorgeous to grab your attention.

As expected from a Baz Luhrman film, the cinematography is flawless as well. The use of fabric to symbolize happiness and the wide shots of people eating, partying and enjoying themselves added a lot to the film and honestly, it all looked incredible.

On the other hand, I did have a problem with this high emphasis on visuals. The party scenes and set pieces do their job, but sometimes they keep going on longer than they should, leaving less time for character development. For example, the character Myrtle (played by Isla Fisher) is show to be very important by the film's end, but we hardly see her on screen or get a real sense of who she is.

I didn't really care for the dialogue half the time either. For the most part it was tolerable, but at some points it seemed rambling and a bit unrealistic. I'm not really sure if this is just my problem though; I'm personally a fan of crisp, realistic dialogue and don't really like scenes of lengthy explanation. It may not bother you but it was a bit of an issue for me.

As for the performances, Leonardo DiCaprio and Carrey Mulligan steal the show. Both actors give a real, almost method portrayal of their characters and never hesitate. DiCaprio has been trying for years to win an Oscar and while such an award is not necessary to leave a legacy, he has a bright future if he continues his career with performances like this.

So would I recommend this film? Well in my opinion it was pretty decent, but as with Luhrman's Moulin Rouge, I feel like this movie is a love-it-or-hate-it experience. One thing that is for certain is that people who don't like surreal "artsy" visuals or modern music will be annoyed by the movie. It's been a while since I've read the book, so I'm not sure how faithful it is, but I still recommend fans of the novel to check it out and make their own judgement.

title: A movie without any story or meaning
review: This movie looks obviously expensive and has some interesting special effects and choice of music but it is completely unrealistic, has absolutely no meaningful story, over the top romantic (yet you do not feel any depth to the characters, don't identify with them, and therefore feel nothing) and dragged out, especially in the second half. This movie is the film equivalent of those 99 cent novels you read on a train and throw away as soon as you're done. It's just a way to waste a few hours of your time. Why anyone would make such a film is beyond me, but then again, maybe this is the average of what Hollywood is able to offer us today.

title: Flawed and Fun
review: At an interesting viewpoint, I had read the first fourth of the book and then decided to see this movie, completely unaware of Gatsby's identity or the ruthless end. I was simply captivated. Whether you love it or hate it, there's no denying that so much effort was put into it, and it is very very unique. I was initially afraid of the party scenes with modern music, but most of the time, it works joyfully. The acting is simply stellar. DiCaprio amazing as usual, and I was blown away by Carey Mulligan, who I previously knew as Sally Sparrow from Doctor Who. Toby Maguire does okay, and the rest of the cast is just incredible. This film is aesthetically perfect. The sets and cinematography are why I go to the movies. I can't wait to see it again in 3D. Be prepared for a very different kind of summer blockbuster. This is not the kind of epic in the same category as Gone With The Wind. It is mostly faithful to Fitzgerald's book, but is open to people who haven't read it. A unique enjoyable film with some wonderful talent put into it. (I'm glad it got green-lighted.) Go see it.

title: Brilliant film!
review:
Nick Carraway(Tobey Maguire), moves into a house on the outskirts of New York. He gets invited to a party hosted by his neighbor, Jay Gatsby(Leonardo DiCaprio). After the two of them meet & grow closer, Gatsby asks Nick a favor involving his cousin, Daisy Buchanan(Carey Mulligan). What Nick doesn't realize is that, this favor will have repercussions on everyone.

This is a great movie. The performances are mind blowing! Leonardo DiCaprio does it again. His acting is flawless. Carey Mulligan is great as Daisy Buchanan. The chemistry between DiCaprio & Mulligan is electrifying. Tobey Maguire is impressive as Nick Carraway. Joel Edgerton is brilliant as Tom Buchanan. Isla Fisher is effective as Myrtle Wilson. Amitabh Bachchan is spectacular in his cameo as Meyer Wolfsheim. I strongly recommend that you don't watch this film in 3D. There are hardly any effects that will look better in 3D. This movie is a beautiful romantic drama. Go for it!

title: The Great Gatsby, the great movie.
review:
What a better way to start my past weekend than going to the movies and finally seeing the movie I was so excited about, The Great Gatsby. This is the third adaptation film based on the great novel of F. Scott Fitzgerald, directed by Baz Lurhmann. I would like to give my opinion about this film, full of romance and drama, that I had been expecting for so long to see.

Taking place in Long Island and the heart of New York City during the 1920s, where a man named Nick Carraway is intrigued by the luxurious life of this new neighbor, Jay Gatsby. He finally gets to meet him, while attending to one of his famous parties he throws very often. Yet, as he gets closer to him he realizes the "gaps" in this perfect luxurious life. A curious outcome happens when he realizes Nick's cousin Daisy, who is married to an old friend of Nick, Tom, actually knew Gatsby.

I believe Lurhmann couldn't have chosen better the actors for this perfectly made film. Leonardo DiCaprio plays Jay Gatsby in the movie. Which in my opinion, he is perfect for this roll. His emotions, passions and obsessions throughout the movie are performed in such a way where me, as the audience, believed and felt all of this emotions. The way he acted, indeed made me feel I was in this position. Tobey Maguire, portrays Nick Carrey. I believe he did a great job as well. He portrayed excellently this confused, naive character. He is believable throughout the film, and keeps the audience member confused and pondering as well. Carey Mulligan, or Daisy in the film, is a beautiful actress which acts excellently. I really like the fact that she is not known actress, like Jessica Alba or Keira Knightley, so being in this movie, really show how great of an actress she is, and not people thinking this by being biased by past films. She shows passion, desperation, fear in a great way. Joel Edgerton, acts Tom Buchanan, in an excellent way as well. His vices, his passions and the love he felt for others is clearly seen through his expressions and way of acting. I believe they were all great actors, and I wasn't disappointed at all by Lurhmann's choices.

What I loved the most about the movie itself, is that is has a great plot. I mean, it is not like every other movie where you know how it is going to end. It has this element of surprise, which made me like it even more. The scenery and the music of this movie was also mind shocking. Every single scene had this awesome scenery, which made me just want to be there. The music was also perfect for each scene, and it really did fit in the scene and time period. Like the scene of the party, everything was just BIG. The music, the house, the fireworks, the music every single part of it was amazing. It truly made it seem like the party everyone talked about in New York City. The costumes were also greatly done based on the time period, everything from hair, to every single jewelry was magnificent. I believe a movie is a great piece of art, when you feel like you want to be there, like you really want to belong there. As in Les Miserables, it is full of music, drama and romance which all want to make you join the actors and enjoy the same experience they are having. Both have great costume designs and excellent makeup that really make you feel it was filmed during that specific time and place.

What I learned about this movie, is that you should be happy with who you are and what you have. You should not change who you are and what you have, people should love you for who you are. Not only that, money and material stuff should not be the way to someone's heart. Also, you should value what you have and enjoy it, since you never know when it will be gone. I believe there are many things you can learn from this movie, and probably what most people can grasp from it, is about love and who you are and what you have.

I believe this movie is for a wide audience, specially because it is an adaptation of a classic literature piece. I would recommend it to those who have read the book, and to those who like Lurhmann's movies. This movie is rated PG-13, and I believe that's a good rating for this movie. I believe people will like it as much as I did, it is an excellent movie, I enjoyed every minute of it.

If I were to give this movie a rating on a scale of 1 to 5, I would most definitely give it a 5. The wonders of this movie just "captivated" me. From scenery, to music to the actors, I was shocked after watching this movie, and it most definitely stayed on my mind awhile after I left the cinema.

This movie review was done by a Costa Rican Lincoln School student, currently a sophomore. It was created for the Film appreciation class of 2012-2013. Whose interests vary from watching TV series, to listening to music and hanging out with friends.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
review:
The things I admire in The Great Gatsby are the things I disliked at the same time. It is so obvious that the plot is so simple, and in no way is it in need of the extravagant production it is packed in. All it is is a simple love story, so I see no reason for there to be a $100 million budget with CGI up the ying-yang and one of the most outlandish costume designs in recent memory. At first, the film comes off as style-over-substance. But as more and more of the theme is revealed (which I never like to give away in my reviews) I can see the reason and a hidden agenda behind this production design, and I really started to enjoy it for what it built itself up to be- a social and human nature statement. Once this was developed, though it took far too long, I could really love the movie. The performances were great and the screenplay is top notch, but it was too far into the film before anything was established. The first hour or so is just useless set up that really took down on my rating for the film. Nevertheless, it is a film worth while for viewing, so I would recommend it.

GRADE: B+

title: "DiCaprio is a joy to watch..."
review:
This year's adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby has been long awaited. Aside from being one of the most famous novels of all time, it is directed by the glitzy and visual director Baz Luhrmann, and with Leonardo DiCaprio starring, it certainly had a lot of hype to live up to.

DiCaprio steals the show and, like Gatsby, keeps the film afloat when other elements seem doomed for the seabed. He is a joy to watch from his intriguing and captivating introduction to his desperate and destructive finale. Seemingly appearing out of thin air, with a past shrouded in mist and with, on the surface at least, an enviable demeanor and lifestyle, he pleasantly evokes Fight Club's Tyler Durden. Luhrmann has said his casting of Gatsby had to be a great actor and a star, and in a world where the star persona is regrettably being overshadowed by overnight celebrityism, DiCaprio is one of the last good guys standing, and the perfect choice for the role.

Carey Mulligan as Daisy Buchanan is also worth noting, in a role that really allows to her to use her innocence and natural beauty to great value, but unfortunately Joel Edgerton's performance wavers, while Tobey Maguire, hazy-eyed and naïve as Nick Carraway, seems to have unfortunately not yet grown out of his red and blue spandex from a decade ago. His voice-over becomes tiring very quickly, which unfortunately devalues scenes and takes centre stage when the audience would much rather be allowed the luxury of seeing a scene play out rather than have Maguire paraphrase for them. A strange and incomprehensible decision to bookend the film with a vignette of Carraway writing the story from a sanitarium distances the audience and adds another unnecessary layer to keep cutting back to.

We know Luhrmann is a fan of mixing contemporary music with period pieces- remember the rendition of Smells Like Teen Spirit in his 2001 film Moulin Rouge!, but despite the great use of a Jay-Z soundtrack, in conjunction with the depiction of drinking and partying, it sometimes feels like Project X has gone back in time, and this cheapens an expensive, lavish piece. Gatsby's own parties are full of the grandiose extravagance we are expecting, but if only we hadn't been in the 1920s frat-style party ten minutes before, the effect would have been so much greater.

With pushbacks and a marketing budget bigger than Gatsby's annual spending allowance, there was obviously a lot of hype and anticipation surrounding the film. Unfortunately I'm not sure it has succeeded in fulfilling this expectation.

As I left the theatre, I was unable to put my finger on how I felt about it. Did it tell me the story of Gatsby? Yes. Did I enjoy it? Yes, partly. Did it make me feel anything? No, not really. And therein lies the problem. There is enough flamboyancy and large-scale magnificence for any Luhrmann fan to be fulfilled, but in a story of character and depth, this is not enough. The special moments in the film were burdened with a wearisome voice-over, and as much style as Luhrmann brought to the table with this offering, it seems he sacrificed substance. DiCaprio is certainly The Great Gatsby, but the film is simply The Gatsby.

title: Great movie. Great parties
review: This movie was great. i felt like i wanted to be in his parties and that i wanted to live in his time this movie made me feel excited when they would show the parties scenes and the acting was great. as soon as this movie was over i immediately looked up the reviews to see if some people felt the way that this movie made me feel. this film was so great that this is the first time i am actually writing a review for a movie go see this movie cause its great. i don't want to give out any spoilers so i wont but I'm just so excited over this movie to tell you that its awesome and its also a great book the movie and the book are alike so if you have read the book see the movie or the old movie .

title: The very greatest movie in the whole wide world every made by Baz Luhrmann!!!
review:
Baz Luhrmann does it again! Not one to rest on his laurels after making Moulin Rouge!, he has outdone himself with his latest masterpiece, The Great Gatsby! Everyone must see this movie! Forge the book. Forget Robert Redfort's Gatsby, Leonardo DiCaprio IS the Big G! What a script by Baz Luhrmann! What makes Francis Ford Coppola think he knows how to write a screenplay for The Great Gatsby? Sure, he's famous, and he lived and grew up in West Egg, or rather, Great Neck, or more precisely, Kings Point, where Daisy lived, but that doesn't mean he can channel F. Scott Fitzgerald, who also lived in Great Neck (actually, Great Neck Estates, the slum part of town). To really, really understand The American Dream these days, you have to grow up in Australia. The American Dream is dead in America. Australia is what America once was.

And just because Jack Clayton also made a movie named Moulin Rouge doesn't mean he can make a movie named The Great Gatsby, too. Luhrmann's isn't just Gatsby, it's The Great Gatsby!!! This Gatsby is hip! This Gatsby is happnin! This is a modern Gatsby for the modern world of 2013 in 3D! The only way this movie could be improved is if it were made in 4D!!!!

title: Leonardo Di Caprio IS Jay Gatsby
review:
Two days before I watched this 2013 version of "The Great Gatsby," I read the classic F. Scott Fitzgerald novel and watched the 1974 film for the first time. The book was about a man named Jay Gatsby who moves heaven and earth, building his immense wealth from practically nothing, to be with Daisy, the woman he adored who married wealthy Tom Buchanan because "rich girls cannot marry poor boys."

This 2013 version was directed by Baz Luhrmann. You will really notice his touch in those lavish and opulent parties that Gatsby held in his West Egg mansion. Luhrmann pushed the envelope again in the musical soundtrack department, as he did in "Moulin Rouge". Imagine making use of unarguably anachronistic hiphop and even rap on top of the scenes from the Roarin' 20s! This is polarizing stuff, you either like it or you don't. I thought it was brave and original, but I did not really like it for the film as a whole.

Like the 1974 film, the story-telling was also very faithful to its literary source, even lifting words verbatim in the narration and the dialogues. However, Luhrmann imagined psychological therapy situation as bookend devices, for Nick Carraway to tell and then write all he knows about Gatsby the man, his next-door neighbor for whom he becomes a close friend and confidante. The lavish set design and costumes, already done very well and award-winning in the 1974 version, were further improved and enhanced by modern visual effects. These will definitely be contenders again come Oscar season next year.

The actors really outdid themselves in this edgier, more passionate 2013 version, when compared to the rather safe and straight-forward 1974 version. That three-way confrontation scene that took place during that hot summer afternoon in the Plaza Hotel alone deserves award consideration for ensemble and individual performance from the three central characters. Joel Edgerton had a more seriously haughty and brutish attitude than Bruce Dern as Tom Buchanan. Carey Mulligan had the stunning beauty and grace that would make it believable that Gatsby would obsess over someone like her. Mia Farrow simply did not have those qualities before, and was so easy to hate.

And of course, there is Jay Gatsby himself. Robert Redford played a very perfect Gatsby: handsome, cool, unruffled, confident. However, the Gatsby in the book is not perfect: insecure, nervous, obsessive- compulsive and maybe even delusional. Leonardo di Caprio, I believe, nails this book Gatsby perfectly. Di Caprio is believable as a Gatsby who may have had unsavory means of reaching his present status. You can see the vulnerable chinks in his armor. Redford looked and acted like he was born rich. My one complaint though is that I think the writers gave di Caprio too much of the expression "old sport" to say, but that is the writers' fault not his.

If there was one factor that made this film a 9/10 for me rather than 10/10, it was the cheesy portrayal of Nick Carraway by Tobey Maguire. I thought Maguire did not look right for the part, and his Nick was too weak, at least when compared to the smart portrayal of Sam Waterston in 1974. Maybe the therapy sessions Luhrmann wrote for his character did not really do Maguire any favors in this regard. When I was reading the book, I did not really get the sense that Nick would become an alcoholic.

In any case, that casting mishap is only a small glitch in the whole picture. This film was very well made and deserves to be seen by all who love the book, or even fans of the 1974 film. It is a vast improvement over the 1974 version. The use of flashbacks in this current version to show us more about the history of Gatsby as a boy and young man was really helpful to understand where he was coming from. The symbolism of the green light and the eyes of Dr. Eckleburg cannot be ignored this time. Too bad I was not able to see the 3D version so I could not comment on that. I can just imagine though how Gatsby's wild parties would have looked wilder or those cool vintage cars racing down the road would have looked snazzier in 3D. Highly recommended!

title: Epic, glitzy bauble of an adaptation; Herculean effort well-rewarded but oversimplified for the illiterate.
review: THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) *** Leonardo Di Caprio, Tobey Maguire, Carey Mulligan, Joel Edgerton, Elizabeth Debicki, Isla Fisher, Jason Clarke, Amitabh Bachchan. Baz Luhrmann's epic, glitzy bauble of an adaptation of F.Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel of the American Dream-gone-awry is near pitch perfect (he collaborated on the screenplay with Craig Pearce) breathing new life into a generations gone tale of The Jazz Age exposed as noble rot in the form of mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby (Di Caprio at his 'golden boy' finest) who befriends narrator, novelist wanna-be-bondsman Nick Carraway (Maguire acquitting himself as the wide-eyed git borderline gullible simp) who wants only to 'be of the moment' with the rest of the hoi polloi of Long Island and NYC - including his fragile cousin Daisy (Mulligan a bit stiff)- Gatsby's quest for love-long-lost/last - and her brutish lout of a husband, racist bully Tom (Edgerton coloring a bit of sympathy for the devil) - all at the question : Happiness yes, but at what cost? Resplendent in Art Deco at its pristine glamour and eye candy production design and splendid costumes by Catherine Martin, the one major flaw is the over-use of anachronized film score incorporating hip-hop (yawn JayZ et al; be gone!) Herculean effort well-rewarded but oversimplified for the illiterate.

title: A tragic, beautiful, spectacular, heart wrenching, and perfect film!
review:
Wow. I am utterly speechless. First off let me say that The Great Gatsby is my favorite book and I am a stickler for movies being very similar to the book. Thankfully "The Great Gatsby" was very true to the book (with a few exceptions of course). Overall it was very true to the book and I actually prefer (SPOILER SPOILER) the movie's version of Gatsby's death than the book's (I liked being able to see what Nick didn't and couldn't see in the book). I thought it was a heart wrenching scene, and I am not ashamed to say that I, and many others, cried.

The cast was exceptional, even Jason Clarke nailed his small (but vital) role as Wilson. I enjoyed Isla Fisher as Myrtle (although she WAS different than in the book, she added some spunk to the movie). I know a lot of people were skeptical of Carey Mulligan as Daisy, I was at first, but she is VERY good as Daisy in this movie. She has the "low thrilling" voice, and is sweet and endearing. Many don't understand Gatsby's attraction to her, but what is often forgotten is how much he built her up in his mind over the years, so of course she couldn't measure up. The entire cast did a terrific job, Joel Edgerton was PERFECT as Tom and Tobey made for a great Nick (Tobey and Leo have been friends for years so their chemistry on screen was very genuine), but the standout (for me) was Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby. He was the perfect embodiment of Gatsby, I could spend all day talking about his wonderful, stupendous performance, but once you see the movie you will know what I mean. He 100% deserves some recognition (at LEAST) during award season (more specifically Oscars!).

The movie is also beautifully filmed, it is quite the work of art. Baz Lurhman creates the green light and the Valley of Ashes perfectly! The music, which is a big source of the controversy surrounding this movie, works very well with the film and, I think, enhances it! Although one track (a rap track to be specific) comes across as an odd and unfitting choice for the movie (in my opinion). But Florence + the Machine's "Over the Love" and especially Lana Del Rey's "Young and Beautiful" are absolute magic in this movie.

Overall, this film is just delightful, I would put it on your must see list if you haven't seen it already. I think it is THE film of 2013 and it will most likely scoop up quite a few awards during award season ( best costumes of course). And some people were complaining that the first half hour or so, is a bit...rushed, and it is at times, but from when Gatsby and Daisy reunite to the end of the film (SPOILER: especially the horrifyingly powerful scene when Myrtle dies) is pure cinematic GOLD! Needless to say I really liked the movie (that's an understatement) and I am pretty sure you will like it too! :)

title: The Great Gatsby
review: From director Baz Luhrmann (Strictly Ballroom, Romeo + Juliet, Moulin Rouge), based on the novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald this was advertised and promoted as one of the big films of the year in 3D, I had to see if it deserved all the attention it was getting. I should start by saying that all I knew about this film was the cast, that there was an original version with Robert Redford, and it started with the words "In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since" and ended with the words "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past". Basically, set in 1922, Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire) has returned home having graduated from Yale University and fought in the First World War, he is ready to begin a career, so moves to New York City to get into the bond business. In West Egg, Long Island rents a house next to the large mansion of the mysterious Gatsby, also living there are Nick's cousin Daisy Buchanan (Carey Mulligan) and her husband Tom (Zero Dark Thirty's Joel Edgerton) who he knew in Yale from the same senior society, they have invited him to dinner. At the dinner Daisy hopes Nick will be interested in young female golfer Jordan Baker (Elizabeth Debicki), during their time there the phone rings, Jordan informs Nick that is Tom's mistress Myrtle Wilson (Isla Fisher) in New York, living in the place called the Valley of Ashes, a section of Long Island. Myrtle herself is married to garage owner George (Jason Clarke), and nearby to the garage is a large billboard with a painted fading advertisement for an optician with the eyes of a Doctor wearing glasses watching over them, with Tom taking him Nick gets to meet the Wilsons, but the party ends when Myrtle's nose getting broken. Several weeks pass and Nick is invited to an elaborate party hosted by the elusive Gatsby, he and many of the other guests are curious to meet the rich man, and eventually Jay Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio) reveals himself, not drinking or joining in any revelry, and he invites Nick a luncheon in New York. There Gatsby tells him all about his graduation from Oxford, and he is introduced to his business associate Meyer Wolfsheim (Amitabh Bachchan) who fixed the 1919 World Series, but later at an afternoon tea Gatsby reveals he really wants Nick to arrange a date for him and Daisy. Five years ago Gatsby and Daisy were in love, but they were split when he was sent overseas in the Army, and she had given up waiting for him which explains why she married Tom, so when he returned from the war he decided to buy a house in West Egg as a first step to win her back. The house he bought is across the bay from her house, and at the end of the dock outside her house is a green light, and with Nick's help they are reunited, she is obviously shocked to see him after five years, but he hopes to impress with his mansion and wealth. Next at Daisy's house she, Tom, Gatsby, Nick and Jordan get together and are introduced to Daisy's baby, and then they go to the city and stop at Wilson's garage for a fill up, and George is convinced his wife has been having an affair, but he does not know who with, and Tom knows Myrtle from the window is watching them. The group next go to a hotel suite, and the truth about Gatsby and Daisy comes out, she refuses to go away with him and any love they had before is gone, but they get into his yellow Rolls Royce together followed by the others in Tom's car, and on the way they pass Wilson's garage and Myrtle runs out into the street, Gatsby's car hits and kills her and continues driving. Daisy was the one driving the car in a drunken state, but Gatsby says he will take the blame for her, Tom wrongly tells George that Gatsby was driving the car that hit his wife, Wilson goes to the mansion, shoots and kills Gatsby in his swimming pool, and then turns the gun on himself. Hardly any people attend the funeral of Gatsby, probably because of his elusiveness, apart from Nick, some servants and his Gatsby's father Mr. Gatz, the true nature of Gatsby is revealed, and in the end Nick returns to the West, breaking up with Jordan, and he loses his respect for the Buchanan's after Tom told Wilson the yellow car was Gatsby's, but he shakes Tom's hand for the last time before leaving. Also starring Jack Thompson as Dr. Walter Perkins, Callan McAuliffe as Teen Jay Gatsby, Steve Bisley as Dan Cody and Max Cullen as Owl Eyes. DiCaprio gives a great performance as a man you are never sure whether to trust or not with his suspicious nature and not fully explained wealthy, Maguire is good as the man forced into all the significant situations, Mulligan is terrific as the beautiful young woman almost engulfed in the world Gatsby controls, and the supporting cast members get their moments too. The story told from the point of view of the simple man trying to make it in business is interesting, the love story going on between the mysterious millionaire and the innocent young woman is intriguing enough, the scenes with big lavish parties and things in the air work great in 3D, and the colour for costumes and backgrounds clashing with some gloominess works fabulously, it is a most watchable period romantic drama. It won the Oscars for Best Costume Design and Best Production Design, it won the BAFTAs for Best Production Design and Best Costume Design, and it was nominated for Best Make Up/Hair. Leonardo DiCaprio was number 94 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars. Good!

title: Great Movie Beautifully Executed
review:
This movie had some overlap with another favorite movie of mine called the mount of Monte Cresto. The first 15 min were a little slow for me but then it really picked up. Leonardo Dicaprio was amazing...as always. The supporting cast did not disappoint either. I did not read the book so I'm not sure what book enthusiasts would have to say about the movie but I, at least, absolutely loved it.

The storyline was easy to follow with good Shakespearean themes that will make you think a little bit more about the bubble you live in.

The movie also delves into the deep, complex subject of human nature, which I always love to think about because there are so many angles to it.

Definitely worth a ticket to the theater.

title: The Great Gatsby ... 7.5/10
review:
Baz Luhrmann's adaptation of the classic novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald is certainly a loud, colourful and epic experience, its even in 3D. But does that style necessarily work for a story as delicate as The Great Gatsby? Oddly enough the answer is yes. This radical vision for the story is very much intended for this generation, a good example would be the modern soundtrack. This helped to make the story feel more relevant as you are listening to music that is current today, the way jazz would have been for the characters in 1922. You can take any frame of this film and you would have something worth hanging on the wall, it is stunning. Having said that, the most engaging part of the film is the performance from Leonardo DiCaprio. He is truly on the top of his game here; giving us a confused, vulnerable, loving and at times deranged Jay Gatsby. That is not to take away from the other actors, I was very skeptical of Tobey Maguire playing such a central character but he too pulls it out of the bag. Maguire manages to give us a compelling performance but also is able to step aside when Gatsby becomes the focal point, pulling off a shift of the spotlight that is impossible to do without dynamic and believable chemistry, which they do have. We are also treated to a good performance form Carey Mulligan and the best performance I've ever seen from Joel Edgerton. I was also surprised to be laughing as often as I was, the film has a lot of genuine humour and charm to offer including a hilarious intro for the character, Tom. The problems in the film lye in some of the visuals, as you can imagine some of the transitions are rather lavish and occasionally Luhrmann will go one too far with the effects. There are also numerous sound editing mistakes, which I found unusual for a film as big as this one. There is a dialogue scene which takes place in a moving car, some of the dubbing is laughably bad as you can see his mouth isn't even moving. The film also includes a lot of green screen and CGI which I don't have a problem with as long as it looks perfect. Anything short of that and you've lost the audience for that shot, this happened a few times during a lot of the fast car scenes which were shot with a lot of 3D-tastic camera moves. The car looked fine when it was actually a real car, it was when they inter cut with the CGI car that it looked terribly clunky and awkward. Putting those gripes aside the film is a magnificent work and a commendable effort to give this generation a new way in to this incredible story, a lot of young people will go see the film and come out wanting to read the book.

I saw the film in 2D so I can't comment on the 3D but from what I could gather this looked to be another interesting use of the tool, much like Life of Pi. I will certainly be seeing this again and I highly recommend it to you old sport.

title: Boring
review: I don't understand the hype. I LOVE the book, but I found this movie confusing and trite, it felt like a conglomerate of fan service, anachronistic pop music, and awful pacing. The acting and casting were fine, but the overall execution is extremely poor in my opinion.

title: Awful adaptation
review: This is a sub-par adaptation of what is one of the best books ever. This movie is not awful thru and thru, but basically a completely modernized version of the story and not a good representation of the book. The movie of course includes the usual gratuitous promiscuity that seems to be a necessary element or precondition of so many of today's films, along with 2000s music, not that of the early 1920s. What made the book excellent was, at least partly, the period in which it was set. However, there is a subliminal (for lack of a better word) mood to the book which the movie doesn't capture, except in a couple moments of genius. I might have actually found the movie more acceptable if it was titled differently, but this is certainly not The Great Gatsby: the movie might be worth a slightly higher grade if one watches it under that condition.

title: Bad movie based on a bad book
review: This movie is bad, though seems to be an accurate representation of the bad book. I guess I just don't get it, all these characters are unbelievably stupid. I think this is a kings robe situation. It's nicely written, but for a generic story. Even if it wasn't generic at the time, it's primitave to say the least, like how a caveman drawing can't be compared to this film though it were the best of its time.

title: Extremely overrated
review:
Really below average film that somehow manages an average rating of over 7. Jay Z was the executive producer of the sound track, so it's Hip Hop and EDM set to the roaring 20's. It obviously doesn't work and comes off ridiculous. This makes the film difficult to take seriously and quite hard to get into.

The characters are unlikeable, which isn't mandatory obviously, but it makes it hard to care when this film is essentially a love story. I suspect a lot of the fanfare over this film is the 20's imagery and DiCaprio, but that's isn't enough to make this film engaging - this certainly isn't a great DiCaprio performance in any case.

title: Not so Great Gatsby
review:
The style is there, the 1920's costumes and period feel, and its acted well, but something seems to be missing ?

The music was not great, which included some rapping ? not a 1920's music so I don't know why it was added to the music score, there was plenty of CGI in it which made it look too perfect, too much like fantasy, and the grimy sections, too grimy, and it did not flow as it should, it seemed a little stilted with too much voice over.

I watched it until the end, but it went on too long, it is timed at 2hrs 22 mins but with about 15 mins of titles, not good.

The original film although looking much cheaper seemed better, and that was not one of the best itself.

I gave it a 6 for the style and acting.
