title: Best Reimagining of the Gatsby Story to Date
review:
I enjoyed this retelling on the Great Gatsby. Gatsby being my favorite novel, it was cool to see it come to life with Leo DiCaprio in the drivers' seat. There was also an essence about it that was different, that some may not have liked or admired. It was a hip-hop, modern, dance type vibe to it. Nothing like you would except for a sophisticated classic novel.

The story is the rise and fall of Gatsby, a poor boy who falls in love with a rich woman, and loses her. In an attempt to get her back, he becomes rich himself, through questionable means. But he is still unable to get the woman he loves, as she leaves him for a man who was born into wealth.

The story is really sad, much like the novel. I am not sure what the moral would be, but I guess you shouldn't chase a dream that seems impossible to attain. You should remain happy with what you have, and what is within your reach. Money doesn't necessarily make happiness, nor do parties and being a popular person.

I am not sure about the moral really, and whether Gatsby was right to be so greedy in life. It puts a great divide between the rich and poor, and makes people scared to cross the line to either side. And yet, there's a sophistication about chasing your dream. It gives you something to live for.

4 Stars.

title: sad and empty
review: It is a sad story.Everyone inside is sad and depressed,Dasiy is the most selfish and timid one who is too scared to love others , and Gasby is a tough one who is decdicated in change the past . He never knows the Dasiy is gone. It's a empty world .no one can survive. As the cusion said, I am within and without it.

title: Just amazing!
review: I have watched this movie for a million times and would watch it a million more. Leonardo DiCaprio played this role in such a way that I guess no other actor could play it the way he did. DiCaprio made me believe that a man can love a woman in indescribable ways. The way Jay Gatsby (Leo DiCaprio) loved Daisy Buchanan (Carey Mulligan) was so romantic and unique that, I believe, every girl would dream about that kind of love. I was completely shocked by the ending of the movie because I could not believe that Gatsby died. Such a tragic ending to such a great movie. I think that the ending made the movie more amazing because seeing DiCaprio die and leaving Daisy in the depression made the movie more realistic. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to know how immense love and tragedy go hand in hand.

title: The most lavish, luxurious movie I have ever seen.
review: I have came across with a huge number of reviews telling that this film can never outshine the book. I want to discuss this film criticially as if it was not based on a book, like many others. I love this movie so much that I cant get enough of watching it over and over again because of a number of reasons. For someone,who is obsessed with lavish, extravagant, luxury, beautiful, excessive life this is an irreplaceable option. Leonardo Di Caprio is the best choice for the role of Gatsby. His performance is so powerful that it is impossible not to fell the same determination, hope, passion, decisiveness, love through his acting professionalism.

title: The Great Gatsby final project
review:
Yael Cerero
Mr. Rice
Film Lit
20 May 2019
Great Gatsby-Final Project
Artistic Value- The Great Gatsby is a film that has many artistic values, which makes the storytelling very good. Its use of innovative style is what has made it such a great film. The use of modern and high-class clothing apparel throughout the film makes it interesting for the audience. Along with different use of camera angles, it provides the audience to really catch the emotions of the character. With these camera angles, it makes the audience feel as if they are part of the film. Artistically the camera is always zooming in or out really fast to capture all of the chaos and parties. But when the camera is on Gatsby it is very still and focused, to to show his deep purity and internal secrets/thoughts that he's holding on to. The Great Gatsby also has done a good job, with its style of music, it has a very modern twist to the 20's style of music. Every song throughout the film has played an important part because it helps the audience get entertained, and puts them on a dancing mood.
The film also has great use of color and lighting, from the warm and cool colors of their clothes to the lighting to capture all the parties and close up scenes. This film had more of non-diegetic style rather than diegetic, because of the music playing on the background and the cast talking to each other.
Entertainment Value- The popularity of this film is the storyline, the writer, F. Scott Fitzgerald's, The Great Gatsby captures and reflects America in the 1920s, shows how the corruption and the obsession of the American people through wealth and status, however it also tells us a love story; Gatsby is in love with someone who he thought loved him back. Gatsby never stopped loving her and he always did things just to see her and be with her. This has made this film to be known as a Classic; a film that won't get old throughout the years. It has become a film that many people have enjoyed and they continue to do so. A couple of scenes that have stood out the most were when Gatsby is shot from behind as he's coming out of the pool, he was waiting to receive a call from Daisy. A very powerful scene was when Gatsby's last words were " Daisy," this proved just how much he really loved her. He never lost hope and his love for her even though she wasn't the one who called the day he got shot. Another scene would have to be when Gatsby and Daisy are gathered with everyone in a room just hanging out and it was a very thrilling scene, because Gatsby was about to tell Daisy's husband who he truly was.
Literary Value- Throughout the film Gatsby has always been a very confident man, he has a lot going on but still manages to show those around him that he is doing fine. One of his internal conflicts would be the love he has for Daisy. He just can't seem to let her go. She was the love of his life when they were younger and before he went to war. He had high hopes that when he came home he would be reunited with her, but came home only to realize she was already with someone else. But this didn't stop him from trying to be with her. Gatsby did many parties in high hopes that one day Daisy would attend and could be with her once again. This all has been a huge conflict with himself. But one of the people who was truly there for him and could see who he truly was; someone who was in love and just trying to get things in his life back together was Nick, he looked up to him, he was one of the few people that Gatsby impacted in his life. Nick was there when Gatsby passed away and no one of the many people who would attend his huge parties were there. He realized just how Daisy truly was, because she wasn't even there when Gatsby passed away.
Educational Value- In this film there are so many scenes that we can learn from and use it in our own type of lifestyle. For example in the film Gatsby does so many things for Daisy but did she ever thank him for everything he was doing for her? Gatsby would throw parties for Daisy hoping that one day she would show up, but never did. This film also shows us that no matter how much we love someone, if they don't already love you for who you are, then it doesn't matter how many changes we make because you will never win, you will never be satisfied. Another thing we can learn from this film is that you can't buy someones love with money. That's simple a phrase; you can't just be spending money everywhere, and whenever you want because that person might not love you back, but we gotta live through it, we can't give up on love. Gatsby didn't give up, he kept going after Daisy, he even ended up passing away but with his last words being Daisy.
In conclusion, I liked The Great Gatsby film. The film was really good, I just didn't like how it ended on a tragedy. I would recommend this movie, I say 10/10. I loved the characters, color and very lighting that was created with the parties or when they would make the camera angles move and how they would make it look like we are there experiencing everything with them.

By far one of the best movie by Baz Luhrmann. The direction in this movie is top notch, the way camera angles are used to narrate and progress the story, just marvelous I say. The overall tone of the movie is wonderfully kept alive by the use of right music at the right time.
In my opinion, if one has read the novel than the movie is kind of a let down. The movie only skims over the story line leaving out the much deeper context of the novel.And also makes the satires of the novel missing at times.
If one watches the movie as a standalone, irrespective of what is in the novel than this adaptation is the best of all the adaptions. The direction, acting and music just top notch.

title: The Great Gatsby and the Great DiCaprio
review:
Baz Luhrmann's The Great Gatsby was truly a film to remember. In the first scene, we are introduced with the main character, Nick Carraway (Tobey Maguire). He is depressed and his doctor tells him to write a story about his memories with Jay Gatsby (Leonardo DiCaprio). One of the first shot is taken with a low angle lighting, which adds a sense of suspense to the scene. I myself have read the book and thought Luhrmann did a great job at emphasizing the most important parts of the book.
I have always been intrigued by the character of Gatsby. He is an incomprehensible man with some tenacious goals. In the film, Nick Carraway moves into a Long Island cottage next door to Gatsby's colossal mansion. We, as viewers, aren't introduced to Gatsby right away, which adds mystery to his character. The only thing we see is the ring he wears on his pinky finger.
Nick receives an invitation to one of Gatsby's extravagant parties. There, he searches for Gatsby, asking everyone around him if they've seen him and if they got his invitation, but nobody really seems to care, they're just there for the party. Nick then finds Jordan Baker (Elizabeth Debicki) and is telling her about all the stories he just heard about Gatsby. But, Nick doesn't realize that he is standing right next to him. The camera then zooms in on Gatsby's ring and we are left waiting to see if Gatsby will mention anything to Nick. When he does, the camera then moves to his face and we see that his mouth is equidistant between a smile and a smirk. His blonde hair is perfectly affixed to his head, and his skin has a pink tone to it.
DiCaprio is the reason many people, including myself, see a movie. No matter what role he is given, he is able to exceed expectations and play the role better than anyone else who would've received the part. With that being said, I believe all the characters suited their roles admirably. At first, I didn't think Carey Mulligan (Daisy Fay) was best for the character she portrayed, but as the film went on I realized that she suited her role very well.
We are first introduced to Daisy when Nick goes to her and her husband Tom Buchanan's (Joel Edgerton) house for supper. She is in a room with Jordan Baker, they are playing around, laughing with the curtains blowing aimlessly in the breeze throughout the room. Then we get a close-up shot of Daisy's glorious ring, which astounds Nick. Then she raises her head up and I immediately thought she didn't correspond to her part.
But, I was later proved wrong by her extraordinary acting. She is able to be elegant, classy, and a little bit sassy, just as I imagined how the character is in the book. This stuck out the most when she sees Gatsby for the first time in five years. Gatsby asks Nick if he would invite her over for tea, so he could see the love of his life again and try to convince her to be with him.
Although, I would like to mention that I didn't like how it seems as though Gatsby is trying to use Nick in order to see Daisy again. Throughout the movie, it seemed as though he did all these things for Nick because he knew that Daisy is his cousin and he could somehow see her again through Nick. But, Nick didn't seem to mind and he was glad to do this favor for him with nothing in return.
Now, going back to the scene with Daisy and Gatsby, I thought Mulligan and DiCaprio did an excellent job at convincing the viewers that they're still in love, especially when DiCaprio gives her a tour of his house. They bonded very well in the scene and you could see the love they still have for each other in their eyes.
I believe they were the right people for each other but met at the wrong time. Gatsby was convinced that you can change the past when you really can't and that's where he went wrong. He tried so many different things to try and convince Daisy to be with him, but there was no way of changing how things ended up. Even if they did end up together, their love would have been different than the first time they met.
Overall, the film was excellent. The costume choices were outstanding and the actors were ideal for the characters they played. However, I did not like that Luhrmann added music from today to a film that is supposed to set in the 1920s, it seemed awkward and didn't really fit in well with the scenes. But, I will say it was unique and a bold move. Luhrmann and the actors did an excellent job at making the book come to life and it honestly couldn't have been any better.

title: Brilliant and Top Notch
review:
10 May 2013. First there was the overly confident young punk quick draw in The Quick and the Dead (1995) and of course the major breakthrough as the impoverished heartthrob of Titanic (1997) two years later, and only a year later the fascinating duel role in The Man in the Iron Mask between the innocent, naÃ¯ve young man and the opulent, narcissistic king. Along with the multi-role characters of Catch Me If You Can (2002), the intensely personal portrait of a secretive life of Howard Hughes in The Aviator in 2004, Leonardo DiCaprio as Gatsby is bigger than life, just as the movie Titanic he starred in. The captivated, close-up starry and bloodshot eyes of Daisy was immediately spell-binding who starred in one of the most memorable Dr. Who television episodes (2007) as Sally Sparrow. Finally, and the anchor of the movie with his co-starring presence in and his strong voice-over storytelling throughout the movie of Tobey Maguire kept this over-stylized and adult fairytale grounded with substantive insight and figurative narrative that captured the essence of fictional writing. As equally satisfying is Tobey Maguire's character's own backstory that begins and ends the movie, echoing the voice over and more hidden presence found in Stand By Me (1986).

The only glaring weaknesses come in the beginning half of the movie where the art design landscape backdrop at one point was too obviously animated in its appearance and the audio track was out of sync with the too apparent impression of the voices being dubbed, oddly in contrast to the criticism that came from the live audio musical singing experienced in Les Miserables (2012).

What was particularly fascinating was the editing and fusion of both movie and novel storytelling along with the incorporation of writings graphics. With the suggestive, visual magic of Moulin Rouge (2001) in the first half, this richly romantic drama brought back the intense relational emotive heart wrenching story of romantic love that made Titanic so successful. The evolving garishness of this the period drama has the similar elements of the culturally explosive backdrop of the romance drama Slumdog Millionaire (2008), the dark richness of the tangled triangular relationship of Interview with a Vampire (1995), or the more spiritual fantasy of enduring love in What Dreams May Come (1998) and even DeCaprio's more recent love interest in Inception (2010).

The romantic connection of intimacy resonates at the same level as period love drama The Reader (2008) or the ending of If Only (2004), the love epic The English Patient (1996). At the opposite superlative end, just as overly-stylized and hyper-dramatic and over the top in the musical Chicago (2002) way or the fascinating visually stunning style of the more recent silent love story of The Artist (2011), the French romantic class A Man and A Woman (1966) captured the richness of the direct, black and white emotive simplicity of romantic love. This movie echoes the bigger than life enduring romance found in the Civil War love story of Cold Mountain (2003) or even one the movie classic of all time Doctor Zhivago (1965). This remake of The Great Gatsby is the stand out movie of the big hits of the 2013 season, making it Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Supporting Actress nominee material.

title: An amazing movie
review: This is my first, VERY short, review of a movie. Simply put, the way Tobey Maguire, Leonardo DiCaprio and every other actor play their roles is close to perfect. It gives us a true idea about relationships and love. Amazing movie. 10/10.

title: AWESOMENESS!
review:
I must say this is one of my favorite movies of all time! It features some very talented actors one being my favorite, Leonard DiCaprio. That so happens to take place in one of my favorite times the roaring 1920s. I had read the book once before but I don't quite recall what difference there is between the movie and the book, sorry!

Let's get to it! The story line is about a young man that grew up poor but had dreams that surpassed his meager existence. His hunger for success drove him to make an unnerving decision, being he was just a boy, to take a chance on his own. This led him to a spontaneous stroke of good luck when he ran into a drunk but very wealthy sailor that was in trouble at sea. His repayment for saving this mans life was to be tailored into what an educated, powerful and wealthy man should appear to be. He was taught how to dress, act, and speak accordingly. This led him to a greater opportunity to be successful or at least allowed him to fake it until he made it. Then, came Daisy! Daisy was a beautiful and privileged woman that captured Gatsby's heart. They met prior to him being drafted into the military. There, just the thought of being with Daisy is all he needed to stay alive. He wrote and wrote but received no response. Though, he refused to give up hope for his one true love, Daisy on the other hand feared for the worst. After not receiving any signs of his existence, she reluctantly moved on with her life. She then got married to one of the wealthiest most eligible bachelors, Tom Buchanan. Now, still with much faith, Gatsby has come out of the military alive and well and ready to fight for his woman by all means necessary. Instead of fighting with fist, this fight was strictly about money. Gatsby had the grand idea of throwing the most lavish parties in New York, in hopes that Daisy would one day show up and he would be able to proclaim his love. By some great miracle, Daisy's cousin, Nick so happened to stay in a little house at the corner of Gatsby lavish mansion. Nick then became Gatsby's lifeline and aided him in trying to get Daisy back. It worked! They finally reunited with the help of Nick and then the lavish parties came to an end which led to much speculation about whom caused this sudden halt to the festivities. After plenty of close calls, Daisy's Husband, Mr. Buchanan has finally figured out what is going on and has also proclaimed his love for Daisy as well. She then realizes that regardless of how she feels about Gatsby he will remain that same poor boy and will never be able to compete with Mr. Buchanan. In a blank of an eye, her once happy life was turning upside down quickly. Due to Mr. Buchanan's own skeletons an unforeseen occurrence has happened with his mistress and coincidentally, Daisy was the main culprit. Finally, due to Daisy's selfish act Gatsby has made is ultimate and final attempt to gain her love by taking the blame for a tragic event caused by Daisy. Only this last chance at love led to his demise. So that was my recap of what happened in this awesome movie. It was a love story, with action that always had you at the edge of your seat. The sound track was also great and helped tie this whimsical tale together. I think everyone should go watch this if you haven't yet. You will not regret it!

title: From book to screen...
review:
As a junior in high school, The Great Gatsby was a required book that we read and analyze. At first getting into the story and understanding the world of Nick and Gatsby was a struggle, but for it to be brought to life many years later certainly helped me gain insight into what it would've been like.

I was astonished with the amount of direct quotes that came from the book. Also, there were a few scenes where the directors literally made it match a scene from the novel and it was wonderful.

Definitely recommend reading the book if you already haven't and watching the movie as well!

title: Fabulous
review: Fabulous. Over the top. DiCaprio perfect. Faithful to the book with Maguire as Nick Carraway looking uncannily like Fitzgerald himself. The book is almost impossible to transfer to the screen as language is a large part of its effect. Cleverly, Luhrmann has thus made Fitzgerald's text part of the movie by having Carraway narrate it and even writing the words on the screen as he says them.

title: F. Scott Fitzgerald's masterpiece!!
review:

title: 2 Hours watching for DiCaprio - watch something else
review: It's one of those movies that you either love it or hate it. I gave it a 4 for the effort for the story telling, great indoor design and costumes. After 20 minutes I felt like shooting myself for not stooping from the first 5 minutes. If you feel you don't like the first 15 minutes then I would suggest you just quit.

title: Just don't get the hype...
review:
Great cast, huge budget, but such a let down.

The movie felt like small snippets stuck together, and as such was very difficult to get into. I have to admit, I almost dreaded sitting down to watch this, as the reviews were so mixed, but with Leo and Toby, it had to be seen.

Not quite sure what Baz was after but the gloss (which I love esp in Meet Joe Black) was so over the top that everything looked as though it had been artificially touched up - adding to the feel of distance to the characters.

I would say, watch with caution.

title: My perception of the novel
review: Here's my perception of this novel which I had to read as part of my school curriculum. I feel that the plot including Gatsby's aspiration for acquiring his love back and its correspondence with the setting really reflects American Culture. Not to mention my need to see the 2013 movie featuring Leonardo Dicaprio and Carey Mulligan who had a proficient understanding of the philosophies of Gatsby and Daisy. Both of whom knew how to portray complex characters in the 1920's all while being persuasive to the audience. Notice how almost three-quarters of the dialogue in the movie had similarity to the book. Also, the physical appearance of Daisy really works to reflect the time period and the role of women during America's Gilded Age. In the 1920's the attitude of men towards women would be deemed ultraconservative if you were to ask someone in this age. Their primary role was to appeal to men with their glamorous physical appearance just as Daisy displays in the movie. You are able to notice with her roaring 20's hairstyle and dress which she constantly wears to Tom and later in the novel, Gatsby will feel satisfied. Leonardo DiCaprio's dress-to-impress portrayal really worked to reflect the persona of upper an upperclassman during this time period. I find these qualities in his charismatic tone, the yellow Rolls Royce in which he uses to take Nick to the speak-easies, as well as his luxurious estate which he uses to lure Nick in constantly. On the other hand, I love how Gatsby's flashbacks which include the one's from his war experience help allude to his rude awakening in the final falling action. The novel as an entirety was a book of surprises and contradictions. It proved that the American Dream for some people can erode which is a theme in the novel 'Of Mice and Men' which you guys most likely have read based what I perceive as your taste in literature on this thread. Francis Scott Fitzgerald is truly a genius with the way he took the audience on a roller coaster with their expectations. You have the appearances of Jay Gatsby followed by the Buchanans featuring romantic themes, and ruined dreams. Whatever impression you guys get out of this novel, I feel the subjective matters are enhanced by the primary themes. Being set in the 'Gilded Age', the author knew how to express the whole underlying message of the time period that shimmering appearances can serve as a cloak for hiding mass issues. Characters like Gatsby and especially Meyer Wolfsheim who were involved in a lot of dirty business had their consciences taken over by lust for money. Wealthy people like them living their lavish lives as part of the bourgeois were only broken compasses if you examine their concepts of morality. I respect Fitzgerald for the way he portrays this because there is a connection to the themes of the time period. Contrary to the common philosophy of the characters living their lavish lives as the beneficiaries of America's industrial boom, Nick Carraway is a giant juxtaposition with the way he is viewed as wise and honest despite seeing those exact characteristics in himself (the bedrock for Gatsby's behavior, funny enough). This is seen in his quote taking place in chapter 3 of the book: "Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known." At this point in the story, Nick is reminiscing the time he spent in West Egg of Long Island with his distant cousin Daisy and her husband Tom whom she was married to at the time. From this experience, he viewed people of vast wealth as being selfish and careless based on the reckless actions of Daisy she committed while thinking being wealthy constitutes being invincible. These actions are described by Nick in Chapter 4: "They were careless people, Tom and Daisy--they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together and let other people clean up the mess they had made." Regardless of how Francis Fitzgerald wishes to convey the attitudes of rich people to the audience during this time period, Gatsby's portrayal definitely intrigued me the most. Now the reason I say this is because the author has this method of deterioration he enacts on the character gradually chapter by chapter. At first, his expressions with Nick help convey a sense of welcome and politeness but that decays over to the point of the tragic death of Myrtle Wilson in which he is responsible for. Nick is able to describe Gatsby's transformation which essentially lays out this novel in Chapter 6: "It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment." This quotation signifies the harm that has been done to Nick who has been viewing Jay Gatsby as his source for inspiration and also represents Gatsby as the epitome for rich folks in this age, lacking morality and turning out as a heart breaker once you dig into the personality. Overall, what I admire most about Fitzgerald's work is that his portrayal of Gatsby, even in the form of a character reflects America socioeconomic state. 10-star rating? I think yes!

title: The Great Gatsby Class Review
review:
In the Great Gatsby, there are four different settings all symbolizing a different type of person in the roaring 20s. The East Egg of long island where the old rich lived, Like the Buchanans. On the other side of the bay are the newly rich, like Gatsby, Nick Caraways neighbor, who are always partying and drinking. There's also the city which symbolizes those who dream and aspire to become the newly rich and pursue their dreams. Then there's the valley of ashes, the working class people that mine coal and other low end jobs.

In the valley of ashes there is a billboard with a set of eyes that over look the valley. On the sign the name, Doctor T.J. Eckleburg, is at the top of the sign. However, they seem to symbolize God staring down upon and judging American society as a moral wasteland, but that's never really brought up. The eyes are just there.

Near the end of the movie, It seems like Gatsby hit Mr. Buchanan's mistress with is car and killed her. Everyone assumes it was Gatsby who hit her as he was driving home drunk with Daisy in the Car because there was the witness that saw the car that hit them and Tom knew Gatsby was in that car. But it was really Daisy who was driving and hit the lady. Gatsby was letting her drive and she spun the car out of control, but never revealing it was really her.

This was a spectacular movie, the way it was filmed was outstanding with it's very mysterious vibe and the actors were all amazing.

title: A great movie
review: I really like this movie because its plot is very enjoyable, but it has also a moral and it wants to impart a message to the viewers that, in my opinion, can be read in several ways. An important symbol of this film are the eyes on the billboard advertising, that we can see several times; this symbol is absolutely related with the opening lines of the film ("In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice. Always try to see the best in people"), in which the narrator, Nick Carraway, told us that usually he does not judge other people and he always tries to find the best aspects in everybody, also when the positive aspects are not so evident. The eyes on the billboard do the same: they are a metaphor of the eyes of God, which looks and observes everything in our world, but God never takes part in our affairs and actions, he never says us anything; however he always knows everything (in fact only Nick and these eyes know what really happen in the car crash) and he also knows that, also if this world is not always fair (for example with Gatsby it is not) one day he will judge everybody fairly. Another important symbol of this story is the green light that we see in the first scene of the film: according to me, this light could represent the aims and the dreams which everybody has, which not always we can achieve; but hope is the last to die, and this is the reason why in the scene of his death, Gatsby sees for the last time the light, he hears the phone ringing and hopes that Daisy has finally chosen him. Daisy and Tom Buchanan represent the richest part of the society, which is used to the welfare, because they have own it for generations, and they could do everything to maintain it, therefore they are careless about all the other person that they meet. At first the viewer can think that Gatsby is one of them, but actually he is completely different: he is a self-made man that was born poor and has made all his riches during his life. Moreover he, unlike them, is ready to lose everything for the only girl that he ever truly love: Daisy. I think that finally Daisy decides to stay with Tom not just because she does not have a strong personality to leave her husband, but mainly because she subconsciously knows that she is more similar to Tom than Gatsby. The most significant locations of this romance are: the swimming pool of the Gatsby's house, which is associated with Gatsby, because during the parties lots of drunk and happy people used to swim in his pool, enjoying his hospitality, but in the same pool he is killed, alone, without nobody that really care about him. The Perkins Sanitarium, which is associated with Nick Carraway, and represents the problems that this character has after his experiences in New York, and the difficulties for him to make sense of what happened. The garden of the Buchanan's house, which is associated with Tom, Daisy and all those people only interested in keep their reaches and earn always more money, without caring about anybody else. The garage where the Myrtle's husband works, which represents all those poor people that work a lots but have a low salary and so are ready to do everything for the rich people. According to me the moral of this story is that we always have to try to reach our aims, achieve our dreams, also if this path looks too hard, too far or too difficult for us. On the other hand we have also to understand when the dreams that we are looking for, are already behind us: we can't live into the past, also if it keeps on holding us, and we have to go towards the future, like "...boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly...".

title: Great
review: 1.)The importance of eyes in this film is an important aspect rather than seeing one point of view the whole movie.The different point of views gives a sense of flavor and interest. 2.)In a way the opening lines could relate with the eyes on the billboard because he quotes his dad saying "always see the best in people" so in that case whenever the billboard is shown its supposed to re-quote what Nick Carraway's father said, relating to the specific scene that's happening. 3.)In my opinion, I think the eyes resemble god or that quote Nick repeated off his father 4.)There are many symbols in this movie that makes it really stand out and more appealing to watch such as, the green light, the eyes and the valley of ashes which are the main symbols. 5.)The old rich and money drove people 6.)There is a moral to the story showing Nicks and Gatsby's friendship but many morals were lost knowing how self-centered the Buchanan are. 7.)Because she doesn't want to be in love and live her life surrounded by money. 8.)There's New York city which associates with Nick and the party life and business, There's east egg which represents the Buchanans and old rich, west egg which represents Gatsby and the newly rich and valley of ashes which represents the poor and labor work held by large industries and the rich which associates with George Wilson and his wife.These Locations associated with these characters because it's mostly what they represent and are there most frequent.

title: Not a great watch, but a good one
review:
"The Great Gatsby" is an American English-language movie from 2013 and the writer and director here is Australian Oscar-nominated filmmaker Baz Luhrmann. The movie is three years old now and it runs for slightly over 2 hours. The title character is played by Leonardo DiCaprio and his co-lead is Tobey Maguire. You will find more known names in here like Carey Mulligan, Joel Edgerton and Isla Fisher. Even literature plebs like myself will recognize that the film is based on the literary work by F. Scott Fitzgerald and there have been many adaptations from this one already. The Robert Redford movie won two Oscars and so did this one here as Luhrmann's wife Catherine Martin triumphed in the Costume Design and Production Design categories. And I can totally see why. In terms of the artistic approach, this film is certainly a feast. It is really good visually and with that I am obviously not referring to special effects or anything, but to costumes, makeup and sets. This is for sure the best component of the film. But there are good performances as well. I am a bit divided when it comes to Maguire here, but ignoring him completely from all awards ceremonies that year may have been a bit harsh. Still, Di Caprio, Edgerton and Mulligan are probably on another level here and they really worked their characters. Admittedly, they also had much more to work with as Maguire's character really only somewhat seemed to be a mean to show us how important, special and perhaps even great Gatsby is. You could almost have a drinking game for every time he mentions the name Gatsby in the first 30 minutes, right before DiCaprio actually visibly participates in this film and story. Initially, Gatsby is treated like a phenomenon, almost like a God and there is talk about whether he really exists. The longer the film goes the more we actually find out that he does and that he is as vulnerable and human as everybody else when a story about a lost love returns to his life and also there is some scrutiny on his possibly criminal professional life.

Is Gatsby a good or bad guy? Is he responsible for tragedy in other people's lives? Can you really blame him for what he does and who he is? It's for you to decide I guess and everybody will perceive him differently I'm sure. While I would not say this was a great watch, I still believe that there are great components to it. I already mentioned the visual side, but there's more than that. Some scenes are also acted/crafted in a way that really impressed. Some information my background here: This was the second time I watched this film I believe. I saw it right after it came to theaters a couple years ago here in Germany and I would say I liked it as much as I did back then and even if it is a film you want to see on the big screen because of its beauty, I still wouldn't say it gets much worse if you see it on a small screen and already know about the events, at least roughly. It was still pretty decent. I have not read the novel this is based on, so my review almost exclusively comes from what I saw from the theatrical perspective. I cannot say I liked or disliked this film more than the book, but looking at critics receptions, both Oscar-winning Gatsby movies did not bode that well unfortunately. Maybe some of them just love the book too much. I myself enjoyed the viewing for sure and I believe this film created 2-3 really memorable film characters that people will still talk a couple decades from now. I think you should check it out and some actors really shine in it, especially DiCaprio who is commanding the screen from the moment he first appears. A must-see for fans of period pieces.

title: What A Unique Film... I Absolutely Loved It!
review:
What a great movie in so many ways. First and for most the cinematography was spectacular. The way they chose to make the film with all the colours and CGI was Aces in my books! It was unique and we rarely see that in film anymore. The whole It being set in 1925 but yet the music was Current dance tracks was Shocking to me because it was so different from the usual but yet I couldn't see any other music for the movie, It just worked!

Also Leoanrdo And Tobey killed it! Tobey Maguire played his character perfectly! A non confrontational guy who is trying to make it in the big city and meets his neighbour who in every way is extraordinary. He plays this quite guy where as time goes on doesn't know who Gatsby really is and in such doesn't know if he should be friends with him or not. As the movie progresses though he can't help but think the guy is awesome.

Anyways Leo And Tobey play both nice but very mysterious characters and they play them in very different ways! All in all the acting, Directing and writing was all phenomenal! To the director Baz Luhrmann, Absoulety Splendid Ol' Sport... ;)

title: i liked this movie, i understood how to "use" my mind.
review: I really like this movie because is not so easy to understand the real message that the author wants to show, so you have to thoroughly understand the film and look inside yourself. This movie is based on the look. there are different kind of people. for example Daisy and Buchanan want to appear as good people so they care of what people say, while Gatsby doesn't care about what the people, so he is very different. I think the opening lines aren't related to the billboard advertising of the optometrist; the opening lines is "my father gave me some advice. Always try to see the best in people," those lines speaks about looking but in a different way than the billboard. For me the billboard advertising represent God's eyes, and that he see and he knows everything. the other symbols that i found in the film are the green light and the weather. the green light at the end of Daisy's deck represents his dream, which is Daisy. the green light is always present in the most important scenes of the movie, in particular at the end when Gatsby thought he finally reached Daisy, but he didn't because Daisy was kind of unreachable. the weather represent Gatsby's feeling and emotions, it changes when Gatsby's emotion changes. At the start of the book Gatsby seems as though he's equal in immorality to the Buchanan, because of the lavish parties. It's only later in the movie that we come to understand that Gatsby has acquired his vast wealth with the hope of one day reuniting with his first and only love, Daisy: but at the end she choose Tom Buchanan because she prefer wealth to love, and I think because she a hasn't a strong personality so she was influenced by Tom. the four main location in the film are Gatsby's house that i associate with Gatsby and his loneliness that was broken when daisy went into his house, Daisy and Tom's house that I associate with both of them plus Gatsby because when i remember their house I always think about the green lights, so i think about all of them, Valley of ashes that i associate with the George Wilson and the place of 'crime', as the crime who committed Tom to 'made love' with Wilson's house and the crime that Wilson committed to kill Gatsby, Nick Caraway's house that i associate Daisy and Gatsby because is as their shelter of love.

title: My thoughts on the Great Gatsby
review:
The importance of the eyes in my opinion is that they represent God in a sense. The opening lines of the film says to see the good of people, which relates with the eyes watching over the people. The green light at the dock and Gatsby's Ring are used as a symbol.

Tom and Daisy represent the old rich folk. I can't seem to figure out the moral of the movie, which makes want to research what it is. Also, I feel I will watch the movie again.

I believe that Daisy chooses Tom because Gatsby started shouting and yelling when Tom insulted him.

The four locations of the movie are: New York, West Egg, East Egg, The Valley of Ashes. I associate New York with Nick because he talks about how he wanted to live there. West Egg would be Gatsby with his mansion. East Egg would be Daisy waiting for Gatsby. The Valley of Ashes associates Wilson and his wife in the lower class.

title: A Elegent and deap movie.
review: The great Gatsby is a visually stunning and colorful film with a touch of many different themes. The theme of eyes through out the movie represents the eyes of god, ever judging the actions of the world and ignored by the world forgetting their god-fearing responsibility and their commandments that once bound society. With their illegal drinking, immoral affairs and back handed dealing. The eyes also represent how much is left unseen by people at the surface level. This theme relates to the opening line of the film were nick says that he has began to only see people's evils no longer fooled by the outer image that people project. The characters Daisy and tom Buchannan as representatives of the old wealth. Well there are many themes in the movie I don't believe their to be any set moral to the story. There are several locations through out the movie such as the desolate valley of ash often associated with Tom Buchanan's mistress in the form of a dirty almost revolting slum, other sets include the buccans and Gatsby's mansions that serve as signs of their extravagance Gatsby's represents this as well as his desire to be with daisy, another set is the humble abode of Nick Caraway which serves as contrast to the other locations. The great Gatsby in question is a man that brings a flourish and flavour to the movie with his elegant and cool swagger although he is also shown to be flawed and looses the love of his life because he is to forceful and in his attempts to woo her he drives her away. All in all, the movie contains a lot of depth colour and their just some thing cool about it its worth a look at.

title: Great, but it could easily be excellent
review:
What is the importance of eyes in this film? We see the billboard advertising an optometrist looking over the Valley of ashes at least twice in the film. Does it relate in any way to the opening lines of the film? Yes it could be rated with the sense of justice Also, what do these eyes represent?The big eyes which appears in the movie represents God and his omnipresence. Also, it could represent the lack of justice that is always possible to feel in these scenes. Are there any other symbols alluded to in the film?The green light in the pear of Buchanan represents the hope that Gatsby always have, major reason why he was so ambitious. The location of it shows where is his hope. Gatsby mansion was used in a very good way to represent how vague his life was despite all parties and people visiting and passing in his house.

Daisy and Tom represent emptiness, self-ilusion and the ego in the story; even can represent the ascension of those feelings back in the 1920's

What is the moral of the story at the end of the book... or is there a moral to the story at all? Why does Daisy choose to stay with Tom instead of going with Gatsby? Maybe because she was scared of being with Gatsby and his anger mental instability . In the end of the story, the moral that the book and the movie left us is the idea of simplicity is what really matters, the appearance and the things of every person is the foolishest part, that times goes fast but we should take care more from each other instead of just living he moment. Perhaps these views transmitted, this story is no more than an analogy with the life and how the things really are.

review: The young Gatsby fell in love with the rich beautiful women Daisy, But the poor Gatsby went to the World War Two, But Gatsby still loves Daisy, he though that Daisy is his future they mailed each other often, just because of this, gives Gatsby struggle of courage, Gatsby met an chance Luckily and his unknown means, made he a lot of money, Unfortunately Daisy married to an rich men already, Gatsby bought a big house in front of she's house. The Daisy is not like before but Gatsby still didn't change, he dedicate to the love, He can't believe Daisy will be like that, all we can see that Gatsby do everything for Daisy, But I think not,In fact Gatsby do everything is to remedy the empty of his heart is to full himself, Gatsby live very hypocritical, At the beginning of the story, Nick introduced many things about Gatsby Oxford World War two noble, But he don't admit his own life, His family is very poor, each time people mention this he will be very mad, at the end of the story when Tom expose everything about Gatsby, he become very mad can't control himself, actually this film is not talk about the love. The point of this film is"there is no hatred between people,only by himself"To'"put down" is probably the most difficult thing in the world, Gatsby can't put down himself dead for Daisy He see himself as the enemy, This probably is the biggest reason that why he will be like that at the end.

title: Excellent
review:
This film is one of Hollywood's greatest accomplishments, in my honest opinion. I read this book in high school and fell in love with the roaring 20s during the process. I haven't been able to shake off that admiration for that era ever since. So you can imagine my excitement when the film was announced. Yes, I know there was a film already made about it, but the thing that really caught my eye was that Leonardo DiCaprio himself would play Gatsby. My admiration for DiCaprio is unlike any other. He's one of the greatest actors of our time, without a doubt.

The acting was exceptional, and the screenplay mesmerizing. The film translated from the book perfectly. Not a thing was left out. It was exactly how I pictured in when I first read the pages all those years ago. Some can argue that Toby Maguire's acting was a little flat, but that can be expected so it doesn't come as much of a surprise to me. The casting was absolutely marvelous. Everything was just perfect. It's one of my favorite films of all time.

title: The Great Gatsby or the great movie which tales the great story of a great man.
review: « The Great Gatsby » is a Baz Luhrmann's movie based on the F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel of the same name and staring Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire. The feature film relates the impossible love story share by the rich Jay Gatsby and the pretty Daisy Buchanan in the voluptuous New York of the 20's. Unfortunetaly, those lovers don't find their « Happy ever after » for the pleasure of the audience... Like every Luhrmann's film, « The Great Gatsby » can be compared to a fussy painting due to the amount of colours that illuminate the screen. It can also be described as a symphony of sounds because of the important place taken by the soundtrack in the ambiance of the film. This multi-artistic aspect is what distinguishes the movie from the other romantic movies. The actors are also a big positive point. They all act their character wonderfully. I'll give a special mention at Elizabeth Debicki for her role of Jordan Backer. She's a real revelation ! Don't hesitate and dive into the festive world of « The Great Gatsby »

title: "The Great Gatsby" IS actually great
review:
Bringing a completely new twist to the classic saying "if it is meant to be, they will come back", The Great Gatsby is way more than your everyday love story. Based on the book "The Great Gatsby" by F. Scott Fitzgerald, there is two films produced, one in 1974 and the more modern one, in 2013. The 2013 movie, directed by Baz Luhrmann, features key actors such as Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire. Not only is the relationships between the characters spot on, the sound track emphasizes the era the story took place in, and the set was nothing short of grand.

Even with the era set in the roaring twenties, the plot is relative to any modern situation. Once Nick Carraway moves back into town, he quickly befriends his neighbor Jay Gatsby. The friendship they form is abnormal considering their different status and personality. Nick's cousin across the bay, Daisy Buchannan, had a prior relationship with Gatsby but ended when he left for the military. However, the connection between the two remained. While Gatsby is trying to steal Daisy away from her husband Tom, the morals between family and friends are put into question.

Leonardo DiCaprio portrays the main role of Jay Gatsby, and putting on a phenomenal performance he does. His transitions of emotions perfectly depict the characters desperation for Daisy's love. He throws massive parties carrying a wealthy and cool composure in attempts to gain her attention. When he feels he was not getting what he wanted, anger would take over and his entire body would tense, sometimes leading to heated verbal or physical altercations. In every relationship Gatsby had, it is made clear to the audience what his feelings towards the person are.

The music playing throughout the movie is relative not only to the situation, but to the designated time frame while putting a contemporary modern spin on it. There is trumpet solos while scanning over the city at parties, houses, or in the streets. The voices of artists are raspy and go into riffs that reflect the influence of jazz culture in the twenties. There is also upbeat songs featuring current artists like Jay-Z and Fergie that can relate to the movie, but also project to an audience in the twenty first century.

Luhrmann does an amazing job expressing the social divide through the set. In the rich part of town around the bay, ginormous mansions line the shore. There is light reflecting everywhere showing how large and bright the atmosphere is where there is wealth. Going into the working-class suburbs, such as the "Valley of Ashes", things begin to gloom. As if there is a cloud of darkness following those who do not have money, people are coated in coal dust and the entire town is filthy. Important even today, the emphasis on the differences in social rank is apparent.

The Great Gatsby brings a timeless appeal that can reach to any generation. Incorporating multiple genres, it shows no matter the year, trends from the past are still present in our current society, and will continue to be in the future. Anyone can relate to the story, making this movie bound to be a favorite for years to come.

title: an excellently adapted piece of art from the original
review:
It's delighting that the movie provides an authentic representation of what the novel is supposed to be. The vibrancy, tempo and narration closely resemble of those dating back to the 20th century Hollywood films, bringing the most of a departed time. I adore the fact that several key prose were made into dialogues and narrative lines; however, the screenplay writers seem to refrain from inserting complex prose that in fact add vivid connotations to the novel. Although this decision is justifiable because the movie should be able to reach to a wide audience as a commercial movies, I can't stop myself but indulge in a rueful smile of a possibility the the essence of this piece of literature can be weaved into another form of art.

The characters are brilliantly portrayed; I doubt if any of them is misleadingly or falsely depicted. This is expected from an experienced and renowned cast like this. Nevertheless, leaving some details out in order for the movie to span a controllable amount of time deprives some key personalities of certain characters (Jordan Baker was not said to cheat in her golf tournament, the romance between Caraway and Baker is not illustrated). Even though inconsequential to the main themes and story lines, the satisfactory feeling is lessened by such small setbacks like these.

I was a little bit disturbed when the script makes Gatsby outraged at the scene in town when Gatsby confronted Tom Buchanan about his affair with Daisy Buchanan. Little does this addition significantly alter the portrayal of Gatsby, yet I still find it unjustifiable to cast in a more negatively-inclined light.

The music complements the movie impeccably. A whole range of my favourite artists constitute to the soundtrack: Florence + the Machine, Amy Winehouse, Sia and Lana Del Rey. I always see a thread connecting their music style together. The Rhapsody in Blue by Gershwin fits perfectly into the context, bringing home the idea of the cosmopolitan and glamorous life of an American in the 20th century. Essentially the characteristic of Jazz is of utmost importance.

title: A tragic love story and great film!
review: This is my favorite Leo movie if I was able to choose just one! I had never read the story before seeing the movie so the whole story was new and a surprise to me. It's got romance, comedy, drama and just many elements. The way they make it look, the colors and everything definitely make it feel fantasy which I loved because it makes me really see a story being told, which it is. I really loved everything about it and every time I watch it I catch something new and am still saddened by the tragedy element as I root for Jay the whole time. Even my 4 year old daughter loves it and will pull out the movie. I love the acting, the chemistry, the friendship between nick and jay, the colors and fantasy element to how they make it look, the tragic romance and love story, everything about it is awesome, I've probably seen it 50 times now maybe more and every time I enjoy it. I love the music of the film as well. They managed to mix modern with old and the clothing and outfits for this movie is also gorgeous. Leo really captures Jays character and makes it his own. Definitely a great film and love everything about it!

title: Hope is a powerful Drug
review:
Hope; that's the word that comes to my mind when I try to think of the movie. The movie is a wonderful drama trying to show us a very grand vision of life's possibilities. I would strongly recommend everyone to watch this movie.

In the initial parts of the movie, I felt that it was incoherent and felt frustrated by the unfolding of the story line. Only towards the end did all the parts of the movie fall in like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle. Nevertheless, the movie is a great experience due to the captivating music and the songs played throughout the movie.

Leonardo DiCaprio amazed me with his wonderful portrayal of the character Jay Gatsby. After watching the movie I felt a very strong connection to Jay Gatsby and could feel all his pain, happiness, hope and a plethora of other feelings. I got this amazing feeling that all the glamour and pomp we might see around in our lives is all just that, an illusion which we surround ourselves in to block out the inextinguishable anguish all of us experience. I am reminded of the lyrics to Linkin Park's 'In the End'.

All in all, I would say that 'The Great Gatsby' is an amazing roller coaster ride and everybody should experience it at least once in their lifetime.

title: A mysterious wealthy man
review:
The film itself, as a film, is awesome. The visuals and soundtrack are captivating and lavish. The acting is great overall, as you can trust these actors to deliver.

The story line is obviously interesting. A man realizes his new neighbor is a mysterious, and incredibly wealthy man. Throughout the whole film, as the relationship between all the few main characters become deeper and deeper, and the questions become answered. You just cannot help but feel so into the character's lives.

The direction in this film is impeccable. The cinematography is marvelous and really lets the viewer absorb the sheer artistry that has gone into making this film.

title: Wherefore art thou Gatsby
review:
An idiosyncratic Australian filmmaker takes on an American classic.

It's a famous story through another lens, but it is a story so rooted in a certain time and place that it has proved elusive for filmmakers.

But with that said. Baz Lurhmann's "The Great Gatsby" demands attention. What he did for "Romeo + Juliet" and "Moulin Rouge" were just warm ups for this movie.

Baz Lurhmann cuts loose with the effects as we knew he would and as he probably should; this is the fifth film version of the story (counting a silent one), and a straight retelling of the tale would have been superfluous, but despite torrents of tinsel, stylised sets and spraying champagne, the story of the enigmatic Jay Gatsby and his love for Daisy Buchanan still has to hit us on a personal level.

I think Jay Gatsby does emerge thanks in large part to Leo DiCaprio, but it takes until about the halfway mark before we can see through all the distractions to get a handle on him.

As in the book itself, there is a long build up to Jay Gatsby's first appearance - like the build up before Captain Ahab appears on the quarterdeck in "Moby Dick". Oddly, the first view of Leo in the role reminded me of Alan Ladd as Gatsby.

All the film versions use narration to varying degrees, and Lurhmann dips into the prose often, following the book more closely than one would have expected, especially the way Daisy disappears from Gatsby's life towards the end. I think Toby Maguire also hits the right note as Nick Carraway, the teller of the tale, although he gets through a lot more business than in the novel. Lurhmann's version brings out the unevenness of the relationship between Gatsby and Daisy - more so than in the 1948, 1974 or 2000 versions. Gatsby has never forgotten her and has become almost obsessive, but she has moved on.

Daisy takes the easy options and avoids confrontation, whereas Jay is impulsive and daring and doesn't mind confrontation at all. Cary Mulligan is close to the best film Daisy Buchanan - not as highly strung as in Mia Farrow's portrayal.

1922 is now far away, but the conflicted emotions surrounding Gatsby and Daisy still strike a chord. I think this is Baz Lurhmann's best film, and Leo DiCaprio hasn't hurt his reputation at all with this portrayal.

title: Ambitious and extravagant like Gatsby himself
review:
I'm not a fan of the book even after doing a thorough analysis on it. But this movie blew me away. It follows through with the book very closely, including some of its key symbolism. The movie did a splendid job in depicting the subtle moods and themes of the story. Visually, it was definitely a feast for the eyes: the costumes, the lavish parties, the cars.

The best part of this movie has to be the perfect cast. To be honest, I was a bit skeptical of Leonardo DiCaprio as Gatsby. I'm so happy to be wrong. DiCaprio did a splendid job in reflecting Gatsby's character, from his ambition that led him to success to his blind hope that led to his demise. Carey Mulligan (Daisy), Elizabeth Debicki (Jordan), and Joel Edgerton (Tom) also fitted their roles very well. The only person that I do feel is sort of out of place is Tobey Maguire as Nick. I had to get use to it.

We all know what happens in the end, but it still leaves me with a dreadful feeling, especially seeing it visually on the big screen. I think Luhrmann did a fantastic job in delivering the Great Gatsby both visually and through the soundtrack. I love the movie, but I still don't like reading it.

title: A Great Movie, Old Sport
review:
"It's so sad, because it's so hard to make her understand. It's so hard to make her understand. I've gotten all these things for her. I've gotten all these things for her and now she just... she just wants to run away".

That quote, is what this movie is about. Her (Daisy Buchanan) Fear vs his (Jay Gatsby) Hope. This movie is, an amazing, and tragic love story.

And the tragedy, is not, Gatsby's death... That rather, was his salvation. The tragedy, was his, outburst. "Non of this, is of any consequence", and that statement from him, was in fact, true. The tragedy is that; In one INCREDIBLY understandable moment, Gatsby lost everything, and she didn't even realize it. She couldn't see that she was being manipulated, and he, couldn't show her. The less he spoke, the more she faded away... Yet still, the more he'd speak, the faster, she'd become a memory.

And what's amazing, is how Baz portrayed the turn of events. A tantrum... Something that seems so simple and instantly forgivable, can turn your whole world upside down. For 5 years, Gatsby worked on an incorruptible idea, however the only perfect piece about it, being Daisy, couldn't realize a simple truth... That, that can amplify frustration to immense proportions... Especially, when you've spent so long, and so much effort, to keep that frustration locked away, so far deep inside you forget it's there, just for it to spring up on you, and create the disaster you always knew it would.

Destroy hope... And you destroy purpose... And without purpose, you're, without.

This movie is borderline a nine... Leonardo was, captivating, and Carey Mulligan, even though you gradually abhor her character, Daisy, to the point of absolute disgust... Her delivery was wonderful. And Tobey was a welcomed addition.

Gatsby? No... The Great Gatsby.

title: Not Gatsby...but So What?
review:
Believe it or not, F. Scott Fitzgerald was not universally adored by his contemporaries; hardly any "great" writer is. When "The Great Gatsby" was published in 1925, critics accused it of being light, unconvincing and celebrating the same decadence modern readers now see as the target of the novel's satire. It's ironic to think that the same insults lobbed at the book a little less than a century ago were used almost verbatim by modern film critics about the movie.

The film starts with our narrator Nick Carraway (Maguire) receiving treatment for alcoholism. He recalls from his past the story of Jay Gatsby (DiCaprio) a mysterious millionaire and neighbor who threw some of the most lavish parties the North Shore of Long Island has ever seen. Nick's cousin Daisy (Mulligan) lives across the bay in a loveless marriage with old-money magnate Tom Buchanan (Edgerton). Seems years ago she and Gatsby had had a brief but fruitful courtship, interrupted by the events of WWI. After meeting and getting to know Gatsby, Nick agrees to reunite the two thus unraveling a complex tapestry of corruption, infidelity, power and tragedy.

In fairness to director Baz Luhrmann, Warner Bros. and Leonardo DiCaprio, making a film based on a universally acclaimed literary classic like this was always going to be a losing proposition. If you thought Harry Potter and Stephen King fans were annoying nitpicks, imagine having a movie be ripped to shreds by supposed centuries of "good taste" who have had nearly a century to analyze the source material. Yet as stated earlier, those same bastions of good taste dismissed the same story nary a generation ago. Are we to believe the film is worthy of the same critical reevaluation?

While the film does have some resplendent moments of visual intricacy, and some metaphorical complexity, The Great Gatsby at times feels emotionally un-engaging and unconvincing. Fixating strictly on the visual, we get the same emphasis on style over substance that plagued Luhrmann's other work Moulin Rouge! (2001), only this time we get to see the art direction without seizure inducing editing. I call this an improvement, even if the outstanding Jim Broadbent is completely absent from this film.

Still, when Luhrmann's superficial approach is warranted the film really flies. The Gatsby parties as well as the fun-loving moments at the Plaza Hotel are infectious. You want to be amid the bacchanalia, dancing the night away, leering at lavish mansion set- pieces and basking in all that insanity. It's inviting, it's seductive and for all involved in the story, it proves a perversion of the American Dream.

I would also like to point out the film's bold choice in soundtrack. While many critics poo-poo the idea of an anachronistic soundtrack, I for one found it inspired and felt it enhanced the story. For the sake of historical accuracy, they could have gone with Cole Porter all the way but by injecting liberal doses of Amy Winehouse, will.i.am and Lana Del Rey, the audience is lulled into a state of comfort. Thus when the story reaches its zenith, even the most libertine of us will feel a sense of moral indignation.

The biggest complaint most every naysayer has about this film is it's "not Gatsby". I agree; it really isn't Fitzgerald's vision and since we are talking about a literary classic, that should count for something. But if the book never existed, if this movie was an original idea, would we still hold it with such disdain? Probably not; we'd probably just brush it off as an entertaining, light and decadent film whose story suffers from its visual opulence. Such backhanded praise isn't exactly an endorsement but it's also not the worst thing said about a Baz Luhrmann film.

title: An adaptation of a book that wasn't bad in the movies.
review:
This film adapts the greatest novel of Scott Fitzgerald, which explores the dark past and love affairs of a wealthy American millionaire in the twenties. Directed by Baz Luhrmann, which ensures the screenplay with Craig Pearce, has Leonardo DiCaprio in the lead role.

The film has a good script, faithful to the novel. Unfortunately, the dramatization soften the symbolism of certain elements. The optician signal, for example, is no more than a piece of scenario. Leo DiCaprio was at the height of his role and, although isn't a particularly inspired interpretation, sought to incorporate his character's personality. Tobey Maguire didn't convinced me, his character looks like a jerk, who drooled over the things of his rich neighbor. The sets and costumes are excellent and show eloquently the ostentation of the nouveau-riche and the madness of the twenties. The soundtrack, which ranges from the strong rhythms of Charleston and the deep melancholy of blues, captures the dichotomy of feelings, experiences and personalities of the characters.

This film is interesting in several aspects and, in my opinion, captures the essential of Fitzgerald's book. Of course, some things implicit in the novel were not portrayed in the film, but that's not makes this film a bad adaptation. Nothing replaces the book and, when we go to the movies, we have to understand that first. This is a very reasonable film. It could be better, but isn't bad at all.

title: The Great Gatsby
review: In the Spring of 1922, the young Nick Carraway moved to Long Island , in a house that borders the Wonderland house of Gatsby , a mysterious millionaire who usually organizes memorable parties and of which it is said all but very little is known. Cousin of the beautiful and sophisticated Daisy Buchanan , wife of a former polo champion, Nick comes to know the past elapsed between Daisy and Gatsby and decides to host a meeting between the two , to five years away . Overwhelmed by the roaring atmosphere of the Jazz Age , by rivers of alcohol and tragedy of an impossible love , Nick discovers himself witness, accomplice and disgusted about the American dream. In The movie, there are five important characters who strive for a dream having in common a deep feeling of hope.

title: This is a fine movie; but whether it will be regarded as the definitive Gatsby film remains to be seen.
review:
I had been waiting with bated breath for many months for the cinematic release of the latest attempt to put the 'great American novel' on the silver screen. This time, strangely, it was an Aussie who was handed the poisoned chalice by the Hollywood moguls. There were several reasons for my eager anticipation. Firstly, I am a great admirer of F. Scott Fitzgerald, and while I personally prefer his inspirational 'Tender is the Night', (which amongst other things, relates the rise and inevitable fall of an alcoholic), I do nevertheless hold 'the Great Gatsby' in very high regard. Fitzgerald was so naturally talented and was such a beautiful writer of the English language that frankly everything that he has ever written is just fine by me.

I can see why Gatsby is considered as one of the finest American novels. Apart from it being beautifully written, it also tells the story of the 'American Dream' – in a country where you can totally reinvent yourself and become unbelievably rich and successful. Although there is much dark stuff in Gatsby, it is nowhere near as dark as 'Tender is the Night' and maybe Americans prefer to exalt 'Gatsby', which they have clearly taken to their hearts rather than the complex and troublesome 'autobiographical Tender is The Night.

Secondly, I saw the 1974 version of Gatsby, shortly after reading the novel, and while it was okay-ish, on the whole I found it somewhat disappointing. Considering the great cast, headed up by Robert Redford and Mia Farrow, I felt that they could have made a better fist of it.

Thirdly, I have long been a fan of Australian film director, Baz Luhrmann. In particular I loved 'Strictly Ballroom' and the magical 'Moulin Rouge' although I was quite disappointed with 'Australia', (especially Nicole Kidman's ridiculous upper class English accent – almost as bad as Dick Van Dyke's much derided cockney accent). So after the somewhat muted reception of 'Australia' I wondered whether he could rediscover his directorial touch with Gatsby.

Did He? To be honest I'm still not 100% sure. It certainly divided the critics; it seems they either loved it or hated it. I'm not in either camp. I enjoyed watching the film and never got bored despite its 2 hours 20 minutes length. Much of it was great stuff and it was certainly a huge improvement on the 1974 version, but somehow the movie stopped short of being really great. The actors, with the possible exception of Toby Maguire were brilliant – particularly Leonardo as Jay Gatsby and Joel Edgerton as Tom Buchanan– and there is no doubt that the movie told the story quite faithfully and used much of Fitzgerald's original dialogue.

The grossly over-the-top scenes of the parties at Gatsby's mansion and the scenes of drunken, drug-taking debauchery in downtown New York were fascinating and highly entertaining to watch. But I suppose I fall into the camp that feels that with such a great novel, the director owed some kind of duty to an American classic and should not have taken us into such surrealistic flights of fancy.

I believe the movie would have been truly great if these scenes of decadence had been portrayed in a more realistic manner; maybe with a gritty, 1930's feel to them. After all, surely they were wild enough as originally written without having to undergo the 'Luhrmann treatment'. It was almost as though 'Moulin Rouge' met 'Moulin Gatsby'. These scenes are great fun – a feast of voyeurism – but somewhat out of place, and frankly, unnecessary. I also feel that the scenes at the motor garage were rushed and could have been longer and better developed, as they are so integral to the story; but maybe I am being picky.

The device of Nick, (Toby Maguire), telling the whole story from a sanatorium was contrived by Lurhmann and in my opinion, was rather pointless. Maybe the Lurrhmann-invented scenes at the sanatorium should have been sacrificed and replaced with extended scenes in the 'valley of Ashes'. I am sure it is all there in the rushes. A Director's cut, maybe? While I still believe that 3D is largely a gimmick which will probably disappear from main-stream movies, the use of 3D in Gatsby probably enhanced my enjoyment, and I have no complaints on that front.

Don't get me wrong – this is a fine movie; but whether it will go down as the definitive Gatsby film remains to be seen. If you have a chance, I recommend that you it. There's not too much on at the cinemas these days that are worth the effort of getting up from your sofa, but Baz Lurhrmann's Great Gatsby is certainly one of them.

title: Gatsby.... an old sport?
review:
**** May contain strong spoilers ****

This is a review made by StoneDraim... and that means that if you want to read a probably different kind of review, keep reading....

This is my personal experience, my personal point of view/perspective and my personal opinion... and my opinion is just one of like 7 billions in this world.

The Great Gatsby. First off; if this is the first time you read anything about this movie, push play and watch it. To take the atmosphere of the movie in in a total neutral way is a great way of being swept away in this a little mysterious story.... this saga wrapped in a modern package, so amazing! If only for the design and the producing of the picture and the shades of colours... The Great Gatsby is worth watching.

A costume movie with interesting and modern twists. A tale told by a contender of his own life, as the time of modern production helps the story moving forward.

Blend a musical, daring dancers, music and emotions from the modern society of the 21st century with a story situated in the 20s.... scramble a little.... out comes Gatsby... the great Gatsby!

Like an amusing park with a little itsy bitsy touch of psychadelica... how about parties in the '20s driven by pumping music of today and the feeling of a circus? Kind of a sophisticated psychadelica...

Greenery and the environments is beautiful.... and the name of the girl is Daisy! Hilarious!

The scene in about the middle of the film (around 1 hour and 1 minute) is magnificent put together. The music, the emotions, the clothes, the joy... the warmth between two human beings in a delicate situation. Nicely done!

There's a little sense of a cartoon in the scenery and the environment... and also a little in the camera angles and shooting of the film. Makes me think of another movie a little like "The Grand Budapest Hotel". Such a presence in laying out the entire cut of the movie.. a mellow feeling of perfection. Just the scenes where the surroundings is absolutely centralised in the exact middle of the screen and the symmetry... marvellous!

Over to the movie as a product: - The production : Beautiful special effects... wonderful and living colours everywhere! The strength of the enhanced colours really makes this one vivid. Great sound, music and picture editing. Academy award winner... and that says it all. - The actors : Leonard Di Caprio use to deliver... so does he here. Amongst other actors, the script is held up by skillful actors and a skillful director. - The story : Is it "just" a vast surrounding of a love story.... is it something else hidden.... what kind of history is this motion picture revealing? - Entertainment : Yes. It is entertaining, and a feast for sore eyes....no....for ALL eyes. - Age : 11 years.

7,7 out of 10. (The final rate is based most on my own entertainment of the movie.)

(Short elucidation of the rating: 8 Excellent movie and a solid production 7 Well made movie. Proper entertainment.)

title: The Greatness Of Gatsby?
review:
For people unfamiliar with F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel and other film adaptations of it, this movie may have been a disappointment in terms of how it ended, perhaps because they were expecting an epic love story. In fact, in the book, the "romance" between Gatsby and Daisy is deliberately underplayed, it's more of an expose of the decadence and carelessness of the 1920s decade, and how the past simply cannot be recaptured, despite the actions that are taken in hopes of doing so. Baz Luhrmann's film does place a large amount of emphasis on the "love story" aspect, which may have led audiences to expect more than was ultimately delivered.

Not to say that this movie is not entertaining or good. It is, in many ways. Like other reviewers, I found the usage of hip-hop songs out of place, but luckily, the film does incorporate music that does seem to suit the era. Despite not being a period song, Lana Del Rey's "Young And Beautiful" works perfectly. The CGI does get a bit much at times, to the point where it looks unreal and a bit too much like animation, but it's still glorious to look at. I suppose that in a way, it was fitting as Fitzgerald was constantly describing light, natural and artificial, throughout "The Great Gatsby".

I can't think of another actor of the past few years who could have played Jay Gatsby other than Leonardo DiCaprio. While not a huge fan of the actor since my teenage years, there's no denying that he is a compelling presence on film. You believe that this self-made millionaire or whatever he was, achieved all that he did through blind ambition to win back his first love, Daisy (Carey Mulligan). I have to give Mulligan credit because Daisy is not an easy role to play, largely because the character was deliberately underwritten in the novel. There is a reason for this, because Daisy is idealized in Gatsby's eyes, as well as in the eyes of her cousin Nick Carraway (played here by Tobey Maguire, adequate but nothing more), although to a lesser extent. Basically, Daisy is someone that others project their fantasies on to. Hence why I've never really believed that it was intended to be a love story, because it was not about real love, but trying to recapture the past, to achieve a dream and attempting to obtain the unobtainable. Gatsby does not truly love Daisy, but the image he had of her in his mind.
